Question: Participant Identification Number (PIN)
Definition: The Participant Identification Number or PIN is a unique number used to identify the patient's (participant's) data.
Completion Guideline: Write the Participant Identification Number (PIN).

Section: INCLUSION CRITERIA
Question: Suspected or confirmed infection
Definition: This refers to any suspected or confirmed infection(s).
Completion Guideline: If more than one infection is suspected, select the most likely and complete the PATHOGEN TESTING section with laboratory confirmation.

Section: INCLUSION CRITERIA
Question: Is the suspected or confirmed infection the reason for hospital admission?
Definition: This refers to whether suspected or confirmed infection with the pathogen of interest if the reason (indication) for the hospital admission.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if suspected or confirmed infection with the pathogen of interest if the reason (indication) for the hospital admission. Indicate 'No' if the suspected or confirmed infection with the pathogen of interest is not the reason (indication) for hospital admission.

Section: INCLUSION CRITERIA
Question: Status of case
Definition: Confirmed refers to a case that is laboratory confirmed and may fulfil the clinical criteria as described in the case definition. Probable refers to a clinically compatible illness that is epidemiologically linked to a confirmed case without laboratory confirmation of infection with pathogen of interest. Suspected refers to a clinically compatible illness without epidemiological link or laboratory confirmation. Discarded refers to a patient with a negative laboratory test and has failed to fulfill the criteria for a suspect, probable or confirmed case.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option that represents the status of the case.

Section: INCLUSION CRITERIA
Question: Reason why the patient was tested
Answer Options: 1, Symptomatic | 2, Asymptomatic, contact-traced | 3, Asymptomatic, mass testing campaign | 4, Not tested
Definition: This refers to the reason the patient was tested for the pathogen of interest.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option which corresponds to the reason the patient was tested for the pathogen of interest.

Section: INCLUSION CRITERIA
Question: Consent:

Section: INCLUSION CRITERIA
Question: Participant (or their representative) has provided consent to participate in this study.
Answer Options: 1, Yes | 0, No, participant did not agree to participate in the study | 2, No, the ethics committee approved a waiver of consent | 99, Unknown
Definition: This refers to provision of informed consent by the patient or their representative for participation in this study.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if the patient or their representative has provided their informed consent for participation in this study.

Section: INCLUSION CRITERIA
Question: Date of consent
Definition: This refers to date on which informed consent was given for the participants inclusion in this study.
Completion Guideline: Write the date on which informed consent was given for the participants inclusion in this study. Use DD/MM/YYYY format.

Section: INCLUSION CRITERIA
Question: Consent provided by
Definition: This refers to who provided the consent for participation in this study.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option that represents who provided the consent for participation in this study.

Section: INCLUSION CRITERIA
Question: Does the child or young person give their assent?
Definition: This refers to assent given by a minor or adult who is unable to give consent on their own behalf, to participate in a study. Assent must be accompanied by consent from a parent or legal guardian for full participation in the study.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option that represents whether assent was provided for participation in this study.

Section: ONSET & PRESENTATION
Question: Onset date of first / earliest symptom
Definition: This refers to the date of onset of the first / earliest symptom which is clinically related to the current episode of illness.
Completion Guideline: Provide the date of the first symptom that you clinically believe was related to this episode of illness in DD/MM/YYYY format.

Section: ONSET & PRESENTATION
Question: Symptomatic at initial presentation?
Definition: This refers to whether the patient was symptomatic at the initial presentation.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient was symptomatic at the initial presentation.

Section: ONSET & PRESENTATION
Question: Symptom(s) during first 24 hours of illness (select all that apply)
Definition: This refers to the first symptom, or symptoms (if multiple occurred at the same time), that you clinically believe was related to this episode of illness.
Completion Guideline: Select all symptoms which the patient experienced during the first 24 hours of illness (select all that apply).

Question: Date of first clinical consultation

Question: Time of hospital admission

Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option that represents the patient's gender identity.

Section: DEMOGRAPHICS
Question: Specify other gender
Definition: This refers to a person's internally held sense of their gender, which may or may not correspond to the individual's genotypic or phenotypic sex.

Question: Date of birth
Definition: This refers to the calendar date on which the patient was born.

Section: DEMOGRAPHICS
Question: Age
Definition: This refers to the patient's age.
Completion Guideline: For participants over the age of two years, please report age in years. For children under the age of one year, please report in months. For neonates below the age of one month, please report in days.

Section: DEMOGRAPHICS
Question: Age units
Definition: This refers to the patient's age at presentation to the health facility.

Section: DEMOGRAPHICS
Question: Height (select units)
Definition: Actual or closest estimate to height at time of admission.

Section: DEMOGRAPHICS
Question: Height (cm)
Definition: This refers to the distance from the sole to the crown of the head with body standing on a flat surface and fully extended, measured in centimetres. For children under the age of 2, please use body length (measured while lying supine).
Completion Guideline: Indicate the patient's height in centimetres (cm). For children under the age of 2, please use length.

Section: DEMOGRAPHICS
Question: Height (in)
Definition: This refers to the distance from the sole to the crown of the head with body standing on a flat surface and fully extended, measured in inches. For children under the age of 2, please use body length (measured while lying supine).
Completion Guideline: Indicate the patient's height in inches (in). For children under the age of 2, please use length.

Section: DEMOGRAPHICS
Question: Weight (select units)
Definition: Actual or closest estimate to weight at time of admission.

Section: DEMOGRAPHICS
Question: Weight (kg)
Definition: This refers to the weight of a subject, expressed in kilograms (kg).
Completion Guideline: Indicate the patient's weight in kilograms (kg).

Section: DEMOGRAPHICS
Question: Weight (lb)
Definition: This refers to the weight of a subject, expressed in pounds (lb).
Completion Guideline: Indicate the patient's weight in pounds (lb).

Section: DEMOGRAPHICS
Question: Race (select all that apply)
Definition: This refers to a geographic ancestral origin category that is assigned to a population group based mainly on physical characteristics that are thought to be distinct and inherent.
Completion Guideline: Select all that apply.

Section: DEMOGRAPHICS
Question: Employed as a healthcare worker
Definition: This refers to a patient that is employed in the healthcare industry.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option.

Section: DEMOGRAPHICS
Question: Patient facing
Definition: This refers to a patient that is employed in the healthcare industry delivering care in patient-facing settings (i.e. roles that involve interaction directly with patients).
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option.

Section: DEMOGRAPHICS
Question: Exposed to biological samples
Definition: This refers to a patient that is employed in the healthcare industry delivering care in non-patient facing settings but are exposed to biological samples (e.g. laboratory staff, medical waste handlers).
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option.

Section: DEMOGRAPHICS
Question: Does the patient practise any of these professions or a profession related to their infection
Definition: This refers to the principal activity that a person does to earn a living.
Completion Guideline: Select all that apply.

Answer Options: 1, Home-working or unemployed | 2, Indoors-office/health/education/hospitality/business/homes | 3, Indoors-factory | 8, Outdoors-animal contact (vet, animal farmer, abattoir worker) | 4, Outdoors-agriculture/forestry/fisheries | 5, Outdoors-construction/industrial/mining | 6, Armed Forces | 7, Student | 99, Unknown | 88, Other
Definition: This refers to the location in which the patient conducts the majority of work related to their current occupation.

Section: DEMOGRAPHICS

Section: EXPOSURE HISTORY IN PREVIOUS 14 DAYS
Question: Did the patient travel outside of their home region in the past 14 days?
Definition: This refers to travel to another city/town or region, another part of the country or abroad to another country within 14 days before symptoms relating to the current illness began.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient travelled to another city/town or region, another part of the country or abroad to another country within 14 days before symptoms relating to the current illness began.

Section: EXPOSURE HISTORY IN PREVIOUS 14 DAYS

Question: History of contact with suspected or confirmed human case of same pathogen?
Definition: This refers to the patient having a history of contact with anyone presenting with similar symptoms or with known confirmed case, or with contaminated material from a suspected or confirmed case (e.g. body fluids, objects, bedding etc.).
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has a history of contact with anyone presenting with similar symptoms or with known confirmed case, or with contaminated material from a suspected or confirmed case (e.g. body fluids, objects, bedding etc.).

Section: EXPOSURE HISTORY IN PREVIOUS 14 DAYS

Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if the patient experienced this mode of exposure to a suspected or confirmed human case.

Section: EXPOSURE HISTORY IN PREVIOUS 14 DAYS
Question: Specify type of contact
Answer Options: 1, Hunting | 2, Preparing | 3, Handling | 4, Consumption (unprocessed / undercooked / raw) | 5, Trading | 6, Animal faeces or nests | 7, Sick or dead animal | 99, Unknown | 88, Other
Definition: This refers to the type(s) of animal contact which occurred in the last 14 days. Hunting includes findings or killing animal(s) for food or sport. Preparing incudes skinning, dressing or butchering animal(s) for consumption. Handling includes touching, petting or sharing living area with animal(s). Consumption includes ingesting unprocessed, undercooked or raw animal part(s). Trading includes animal contact from selling, buying or exchanging animal(s). Animal faeces or nests includes contact with faeces, nests or homes of animal(s). Sick or dead animals refers to contact with a sick or dead animal but not participation in animal surgery or nercopsy (seperate question).
Completion Guideline: Select all the type(s) of animal contact which occurred in the last 14 days.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Neurological comorbidities
Definition: This refers to comorbidities relating to the nervous system.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Chronic neurological disorder
Definition: Includes disorders of the brain, spinal cord, cranial nerves, peripheral nerves, nerve roots, autonomic nervous system, neuromuscular junction, and muscle. This can include any of cerebral palsy, multiple sclerosis, motor neurone disease, muscular dystrophy, myasthenia gravis, Parkinson's disease, stroke, and severe learning difficulty.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Epilepsy
Definition: This refers to a disorder causing recurrent unprovoked seizures
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at any time from onset of this illness to presentation.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Dementia
Definition: Defined as evidence from the history and mental status examination that indicates major impairment in learning and memory as well as impairment in at least one of the following: handling complex tasks; reasoning ability; spatial ability and orientation; language. The cognitive symptoms must significantly interfere with the individual's work performance, usual social activities, or relationships with other people. This must represent a significant decline from a previous level of functioning. The disturbances are not occurring exclusively during the course of delirium, and the disturbances are not better accounted for by a major psychiatric diagnosis. Chronic cognitive deficit is included.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Stroke / cerebrovascular accident
Definition: Defined as a sudden loss of neurological function secondary to haemorrhage or ischemia in the brain parenchyma due to a vascular event. Stroke may be a clinical diagnosis, with or without supportive radiological findings.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Hemiplegia
Definition: This refers to severe or complete loss of motor function on one side of the body; often caused by brain diseases that are localized to the cerebral hemisphere opposite to the side of weakness; less frequently, brain stem lesions; cervical spinal cord diseases, peripheral nervous system diseases, and other conditions may manifest as hemiplegia.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Paraplegia
Definition: This refers to complete paralysis of the lower half of the body including both legs, often caused by damage to the spinal cord.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Cardiovascular comorbidities
Definition: This refers to comorbidities relating to the cardiovascular system.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Chronic cardiac disease (not hypertension)
Definition: Defined as a disease that progressively causes deterioration of the heart and its functioning. This includes congenital heart diseases (e.g. tetralogy of fallot)
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Myocardial infarction
Definition: Defined as gross necrosis of the myocardium, as a result of interruption of the blood supply to the area, as in coronary thrombosis. This includes previous (history of) myocardial infarction.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Congestive heart failure
Definition: Defined as failure of the heart to pump a sufficient amount of blood to meet the needs of the body tissues, resulting in tissue congestion and oedema.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Hypertension
Definition: Defined as elevated arterial blood pressure diagnosed clinically (systolic blood pressure >140mmHg systolic and/or diastolic blood pressure >90mmHg), or for which a patient is prescribed an anti-hypertensive.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Peripheral vascular disease
Definition: This refers to deviation from or interruption of the normal structure or function of the blood vessels outside the heart; diseases of the peripheral as opposed to the cardiac circulation.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Respiratory comorbidities
Definition: This refers to comorbidities relating to the respiratory system.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Chronic pulmonary disease (not asthma)
Definition: Defined as any pulmonary condition other than asthma, that is a disease or disorder of slow progression and long duration which causes continuous or episodic periods of illness and/or incapacity.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Asthma
Definition: This is defined as clinician-diagnosed asthma, a chronic airway disorder characterized by variable and recurring symptoms of airflow obstruction, bronchial hyper-responsiveness, and/or underlying inflammation. Current pharmaceutical intervention - for prevention or treatment of symptoms - is not a pre-requisite for the inclusion of this diagnosis.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Gastrointestinal comorbidities
Definition: This refers to comorbidities relating to the gastrointestinal system.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Peptic ulcer disease
Definition: This refers to acid peptic injury of the digestive tract, resulting in mucosal break reaching the submucosa. Peptic ulcers are usually located in the stomach or proximal duodenum, but they can also be found in the oesophagus or Meckel's diverticulum.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Liver disease
Definition: Defined as any disorder of the hepatobiliary system. Manifestations may include signs and symptoms of cholestasis, portal hypertension, and/or abnormal liver function tests.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission and is ongoing.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Type of liver disease
Definition: Defined as mild - chronic hepatitis or cirrhosis without portal hypertension, and moderate or severe - cirrhosis with portal hypertension, with or without bleeding or a history of variceal bleeding.
Completion Guideline: Indicate the type of liver disease. Mild: chronic hepatitis or cirrhosis without portal hypertension. Moderate or severe: cirrhosis with portal hypertension, with or without bleeding or a history of variceal bleeding.

Metathesaurus: C0023895, Liver diseases | C2945599, mild (qualifier value) | C1299393, moderate to severe (qualifier value)

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Renal / Genitourinary comorbidities
Definition: This refers to comorbidities relating to the renal / genitourinary system.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Chronic kidney disease
Definition: This is defined as a clinician-diagnosed chronic kidney disease (CKD, also known as chronic kidney failure). The KDIGO and KDOQI definition of chronic kidney disease is kidney damage for 3 months, as defined by structural or functional abnormalities of the kidney, with or without decreased glomerular filtration rate (GFR), that can lead to decreased GFR, manifest by either: Pathologic abnormalities; or Markers of kidney damage, including abnormalities in the composition of the blood or urine, or abnormalities in imaging tests; or GFR <60 mL/min/1.73 m^2 for 3 months, with or without kidney damage.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Stage of chronic kidney disease
Answer Options: 1, Stage 1 | 2, Stage 2 | 3, Stage 3a | 4, Stage 3b | 5, Stage 4 | 6, Stage 5 | 99, Unknown
Definition: This refers to the stage of chronic kidney disease (CKD) based on estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR). CKD Stages: 1 - Kidney damage, normal eGFR (90ml/min); 2 - Kidney damage, mild GFR decrease (60-89ml/min); 3a - Moderate GFR decrease (45-59ml/min); 3b - Moderate to severe GFR decrease (30-44ml/min); 4 - Severe GFR decrease (15-29ml/min); 5 - Kidney failure (<15ml/min or on dialysis).
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option that corresponds to the stage of CKD based on eGFR.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Infectious comorbidities
Definition: This refers to infection-related comorbidities.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: HIV
Definition: Defined as a person living with laboratory-confirmed Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) 1 or 2 infection, or a patient with an Acquired Immunity Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) defining illness. This is irrespective of the CD4 lymphocyte count/percentage or HIV viral load in blood. ART refers to anti-retroviral therapy and is distinct from pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) or post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP).
Completion Guideline: Indicate the single most appropriate option that reflects the HIV/AIDS status of the patient and whether they are taking anti-retroviral therapy (ART).
Standardized Term Code: 19030005, Human immunodeficiency virus | 62479008, Acquired immune deficieny syndrome
Metathesaurus: C0019693, HIV Infection | C0001175, Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Is the patient on anti-retroviral therapy (ART)?
Definition: Anti-retroviral therapy (ART) refers to drug therapy, for patients with HIV infection, which targets retrovirus function by multiple mechanisms to aggressively suppress HIV replication. It is distinct from pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) or post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP).
Completion Guideline: Indicate the single most appropriate option that reflects the HIV/AIDS status of the patient and whether they are taking anti-retroviral therapy (ART).

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Specify ART
Definition: This refers to antiretroviral therapy (ART) used in treatment of HIV infections with medications that target the virus directly, limiting the ability of infected cells to produce new virus particles. It is distinct from pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) or post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP).
Completion Guideline: Write the antiretroviral therapy (ART) drugs being used in treatment of HIV.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: If HIV positive: CD4 count date
Definition: This refers to the date of the most recent laboratory-based CD4 cell count available.
Completion Guideline: Write the date in DD/MM/YYYY format.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: If HIV positive: Most recent CD4 count (cells/uL)
Definition: This refers to the date of the most recent laboratory-based CD4 cell count available.
Completion Guideline: Write the date in DD/MM/YYYY format.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: If HIV positive: Is HIV viral load detectable
Definition: Detectable typically includes suppressed (detected but <= 1000 copies/mL) and unsuppressed (>1000 copies/mL). Undetectable refers to viral load not detected by test used.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if detectable (includes; suppressed (detected but <= 1000 copies/mL) and unsuppressed (>1000 copies/mL)). Indicate 'No' if undetectable (viral load not detected by test used).

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Most recent HIV viral load (copies/mL)
Definition: Defined as the most recent laboratory-based HIV viral load available expressed in copies/mL.
Completion Guideline: Indicate the most recent laboratory-based HIV viral load available expressed in copies/mL.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Tuberculosis
Definition: Defined as patients currently receiving treatment for tuberculosis, an infection caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Latent tuberculosis should not be included here. Patients who have been cured of tuberculosis should not be included here. Those who have chronic pulmonary sequelae following their tuberculosis should be included as chronic pulmonary disease.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Specify tuberculosis type
Answer Options: 1, Active pulmonary | 4, Active extra-pulmonary | 3, Latent | 99, Unknown
Definition: This refers to the type of Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection. Active pulmonary TB refers to bacterial infection that affects the lungs and is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, with signs and symptoms including chronic cough with blood-tinged sputum, night sweats, fever, fatigue, and weight loss. Active extra-pulmonary TB refers to Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection involving organs other than the lungs (e.g., pleura, lymph nodes, abdomen, genitourinary tract, skin, joints and bones, or meninges). Latent TB refers to the asymptomatic presence of Mycobacterium tuberculosis in the body, which is determined by a positive result to a tuberculin skin test or interferon-gamma release assay.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option(s) that represents the type of Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection.
Standardized Term Code: 154283005, Pulmonary tuberculosis (disorder) | 423997002, Tuberculosis, extrapulmonary (disorder) | 11999007, Inactive tuberculosis (finding)

Question: Chronic hepatitis B/C infection
Definition: Defined as chronic hepatitis due to infection by hepatitis B (HBV) or hepatitis C (HCV) virus. Do not include those with a documented cure of hepatitis C.

Question: Chronic haematologic disease

Does not include leukaemia, lymphoma or myeloma, which should be entered under malignancy. Does not include iron-deficiency anaemia which is explained by diet or chronic blood loss.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition.

Question: Sickle cell disease
Definition: This refers to a genetic blood disorder characterized by the appearance of sickle-shaped red blood cells and anemia.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Systemic / general comorbidities
Definition: This refers to systemic / general comorbidities.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Prematurity (<37 weeks)
Definition: This refers to birth when a fetus is less than 37 weeks and 0 days gestational age.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Rheumatologic disorder
Definition: Defined as an disorders of connective tissue, especially the joints and related structures characterised by inflammation, degeneration or metabolic derangement. It includes chronic arthropathies and arthritis, connective tissue disorders and vasculitides.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Asplenia
Definition: Defined as the anatomical absence of the spleen or functional asplenia secondary to a variety of disease states. This can include congenital absence (born without a spleen), or acquired absence, for example secondary to surgical removal.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Benign neoplasm
Definition: This refers to a neoplasm characterized by the absence of atypical or malignant cytological and architectural features, and absence of invasive features or metastatic potential.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Malignant neoplasm
Definition: Defined as a tumour composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Includes haematological malignancies, that are considered to be biologically active. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukaemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. It specifically does not include malignancies that have been cured or where there is no evidence of on-going disease relating to that malignancy following treatment.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Malignant solid neoplasm
Definition: Defined as a malignant neoplasm arising from tissues that do not include fluid areas. Representative examples include carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas) and sarcomas. Hematopoietic and lymphoid tissue malignancies are not considered solid neoplasms.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Leukemia
Definition: Defined as a progressive, malignant disease of the blood-forming organs, characterized by distorted proliferation and development of leukocytes and their precursors in the blood and bone marrow. Leukemias were originally termed acute or chronic based on life expectancy but now are classified according to cellular maturity.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Lymphoma
Definition: Defined as a malignant (clonal) proliferation of B- lymphocytes or T- lymphocytes which involves the lymph nodes, bone marrow and/or extranodal sites. This category includes Non-Hodgkin lymphomas and Hodgkin lymphomas.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Obesity
Definition: Refers to body weight grossly above recommended standard. BMI >= 30 kg/m2 or other locally appropriate BMI cut off can be used to define obesity.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Malnutrition
Definition: This refers to any clinically identified deficiency in intake, either of total energy or of specific nutrients, that led to a dietetic intervention or referral prior to this admission.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Diabetes mellitus
Definition: Defined as a metabolic disorder characterized by abnormally high blood sugar levels due to diminished production of insulin or insulin resistance or desensitization. This includes Type 1 diabetes mellitus, Type 2 diabetes mellitus, or Gestational diabetes requiring oral or subcutaneous treatment.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: Diabetes mellitus type
Definition: Refers to a subtype of diabetes mellitus that is characterized by insulin deficiency; it is manifested by the sudden onset of severe hyperglycemia, rapid progression to diabetic ketoacidosis, and death unless treated with insulin; the disease may occur at any age, but is most common in childhood or adolescence.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: End organ damage from diabetes
Definition: Refers to irreparable damage to multiple organs/systems which is the result of chronic complications of diabetes. The affected organs/systems include the cardiovascular system, kidneys, eyes, nervous system, joints and feet.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: HbA1C result within last 6 months (select units)
Definition: Haemoglobin A1C (HbA1C) is a blood test that measures average blood glucose level over the three months preceding the test result. It can be reported in different units (mmol/mol, mmol/L or %).
Completion Guideline: Select the option that best fits the result. If there is no result for the patient in the last six months proceed onto the next question.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: HbA1C result within last 6 months (mmol/mol)
Definition: Haemoglobin A1C (HbA1C) is a blood test that measures average blood glucose level over the three months preceding the test result. It can be reported in different units (mmol/mol, mmol/L or %).
Completion Guideline: Enter the numerical value for HbA1C level expressed in mmol/mol.

Section: CO-MORBIDITIES AND RISK FACTORS: Existing prior to this current illness and is ongoing
Question: HbA1C result within last 6 months (mmol/L)
Definition: Estimated average glucose (eAG) can be calculated from HbA1C or reported separately in the units of mmol/L (similar to blood glucose levels). The relationship between HbA1C and eAG is described by: 28.7 x HbA1C - 46.7 = eAG.
Completion Guideline: Enter the numerical value for eAG level expressed in mmol/L.

Completion Guideline: Enter the numerical value for HbA1C level expressed as a percentage %.

Question: Ever smoked
Definition: This refers to smoking cigarettes, cigars, pipes or equivalent. Never smoker is defined as a person who has never smoked at the time of the assessment or has smoked less than 100 of the above items in their life. Do not include smoke-free tobacco products such as chewed tobacco or electronic nicotine delivery devices.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition. Indicate 'No' if the patient has never smoked (defined as a person who has never smoked at the time of the assessment or has smoked less than 100 of the above items in their life).

Section: MEDICAL HISTORY
Question: Known to have previous chickenpox infection(s)?
Definition: This refers to a previous chickenpox infection. It does not include a history of reactived Varicella zoster virus (VZV) i.e. Shingles.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition.

Section: MEDICAL HISTORY
Question: Active chickenpox
Definition: This refers to active chickenpox infection caused by varicella-zoster virus. Clinical manifestations are fever and pruritic, vesicular skin rash occurring ten to twenty-one days after exposure. Do not include those with reactived Varicella zoster virus (VZV) i.e. Shingles.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition.

Section: MEDICAL HISTORY
Question: Active shingles (herpes zoster)
Definition: This refers to an active case of shingles or herpes zoster dues to the reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus that has remained dormant, after the patient's initial exposure to the virus in the form of varicella (chickenpox).
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient currently has shingles (herpes zoster), a reactivation of varicella-zoster virus. Indicate 'No' if the patient has only had chickenpox in the past, or if the patient does not have a history of this condition.

Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient currently has active hepatitis C infection

Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this is condition existed prior to admission with this current illness and remains an active medical condition.

Question: Antiviral
Definition: An antiviral agent refers to any agent(s) prescribed to treat or prevent viral infections by interfering with the viral replication cycle. Examples of neuraminidase inhibitors include oseltamivir, ribavirin, acyclovir and lopinavir/ritonavir. Topical preparations are not included.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has taken an antiviral in the 14 days prior to this most recent admission / presentation

Section: MEDICATION PRIOR TO THIS HOSPITALIZATION
Question: Antiviral administration route
Definition: This refers to the part of the body through which or into which, or the way in which, the medicinal product (drug) is introduced. Oral refers to administering by mouth. Inhaled refers to administration through the respiratory route (insufflation into the respiratory tract). IV (intravenous) refers to administering into bloodstream through injection into a vein. Topical refers to administration by application of drug preparations to the surfaces of the body, especially the skin or mucous membranes.
Completion Guideline: Indicate the route of administration for the antiviral agent.
Standardized Term Code: 386359008, Administration of drug or medicament via oral route (procedure) | 243132000, Inhaled drug administration (procedure) | 386358000, Administration of drug or medicament via intravenous route (procedure) | 431695009, Administration of drug or medicament to skin via topical route (procedure)

Section: MEDICATION PRIOR TO THIS HOSPITALIZATION
Question: Corticosteroid
Definition: Corticosteroids (commonly referred to as 'steroids') refers to all types of therapeutic corticosteroid, made in the adrenal cortex (the outer part of the adrenal gland). They are also made in the laboratory. Examples include: prednisolone, prednisone, methyl-prednisolone, dexamethasone, hydrocortisone, fluticasone, betametasone. Topical preparations are not included, but inhaled preparations are included.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has taken a 'steroid' in the 14 days prior to this most recent admission / presentation

Section: MEDICATION PRIOR TO THIS HOSPITALIZATION
Question: NSAIDs
Definition: Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs or NSAIDS refers to any agent that is not a corticosteroid and has potential anti-inflammatory, analgesic, antipyretic and anti-platelet activities. Most nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) act by inhibiting the conversion of arachidonic acid to the precursors of prostaglandin and thromboxane by cyclooxygenase enzymes. Topical preparations should not be recorded.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has taken an NSAID in the 14 days prior to this most recent admission / presentation

Question: Anticoagulant
Definition: An anticoagulant refers to any agent capable of preventing blood clot formation, or platelet aggregation. This includes agents such as heparin, warfarin, aspirin, clopidogrel, and subcutaneously administered anticoagulants, among many others. Topical preparations are not included.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has taken an anticoagulant in the 7 days prior to this most recent admission / presentation.

Section: MEDICATION PRIOR TO THIS HOSPITALIZATION
Question: Intravenous (parenteral) fluids
Definition: Intravenous (IV) or parenteral fluids are prescribed as a replacement of fluid, electrolytes, calories, vitamins, and other nutritional substances. Intravenous fluids may be used for rehydration, maintenance requirements or resuscitation.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if the patient received intravenous fluids in the 7 days prior to this most recent admission / presentation.

Section: MEDICATION PRIOR TO THIS HOSPITALIZATION
Question: Intravenous fluid type
Definition: This refers to the type of parenteral or intravenous (IV) fluid is prescribed as a replacement of fluid, electrolytes, calories, vitamins, and other nutritional substances. Intravenous fluids may be crystalloids (commonly including 0.9% Sodium Chloride (Normal Saline), Lactated Ringer(USP), 0.45% Sodium Chloride (Half-normal saline), 0.45% normal saline + 4% Glucose (Half-normal saline with dextrose), 0.18%-0.3% Sodium Chloride + 4% Glucose (Hypotonic saline with dextrose), 5% Glucose (Dextrose 5% in Water), Ringeracetate or Plasmalyte) or colloids (commonly including gelatins, starches or albumin).
Completion Guideline: Select the intravenous fluid(s) prescribed or taken by the patient in the 14 days prior to this most recent admission / presentation

Completion Guideline: Specify the total volume of the intravenous fluids (crystalloids and colloids) received by the patient over the previous 24 hours. Record the volume in millilitres (mL).

Section: MEDICATION PRIOR TO THIS HOSPITALIZATION
Question: Indication / reason
Answer Options: 1, Shock | 2, High/rising haematocrit | 3, Anorexia | 4, Persistent vomiting | 88, Other
Definition: This refers to the indication for intravenous fluids. Shock refers to circulatory failure, causing inadequate oxygen delivery to meet cellular metabolic needs. It is characterised by any two of the following: evidence of hypoperfusion (e.g. slow capillary refill, cold skin, and rapid and weak pulse), narrow pulse pressure (less than or equal to 20mmHg), hypotension for age, and tachycardia.
Completion Guideline: Indicate the indication for intravenous fluids.

Section: MEDICATION PRIOR TO THIS HOSPITALIZATION
Question: Specify other reason
Definition: This refers to the indication for intravenous fluids. Shock refers to circulatory failure, causing inadequate oxygen delivery to meet cellular metabolic needs. It is characterised by any two of the following: evidence of hypoperfusion (e.g. slow capillary refill, cold skin, and rapid and weak pulse), narrow pulse pressure (less than or equal to 20mmHg), hypotension for age, and tachycardia.
Completion Guideline: If 'Other', write the indication for intravenous fluids.

Section: MEDICATION PRIOR TO THIS HOSPITALIZATION
Question: Antihypertensives
Definition: This refers to any substance used in the treatment of acute or chronic hypertension regardless of pharmacological mechanism. Examples include: ACE Inhibitors (Lisinopril (Zestril), Enalapril (Vasotec), Ramipril (Altace), Captopril); Angiotensin Receptor Blockers ((Losartan (Cozaar), Valsartan (Diovan), Irbesartan (Avapro), Olmesartan (Benicar)); Beta-Blockers (Metoprolol (Lopressor), Carvedilol (Coreg), Bisoprolol, Atenolol); Calcium Channel Blockers (Amlodipine (Norvasc), Diltiazem (Cardizem), Verapamil); Diuretics (Furosemide (Lasix), Spironolactone (Aldactone), Hydrochlorothiazide (HCTZ))
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has taken this medication in the 14 days prior to this most recent admission / presentation

Section: MEDICATION PRIOR TO THIS HOSPITALIZATION
Question: Antidiabetic medications
Definition: This refers to any substance used to reduce hyperglycemia or treat disorders associated with diabetes. Examples include: Metformin (Glucophage); SGLT2 Inhibitors (Empagliflozin (Jardiance), Dapagliflozin (Farxiga), Canagliflozin (Invokana)); DPP-4 Inhibitors (Sitagliptin (Januvia), Linagliptin (Tradjenta), Saxagliptin (Onglyza)); GLP-1 Receptor Agonists (Liraglutide (Victoza), Semaglutide (Ozempic), Dulaglutide (Trulicity)); Insulins (Glargine (Lantus), Aspart (NovoLog), Lispro (Humalog), Detemir (Levemir))
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has taken this medication in the 14 days prior to this most recent admission / presentation

Section: MEDICATION PRIOR TO THIS HOSPITALIZATION
Question: Lipid-lowering drugs
Definition: This refers to any substance used to lower the levels of certain lipids in the blood in the treatment of hyperlipidaemias. Examples include: Statins (Atorvastatin (Lipitor), Rosuvastatin (Crestor), Simvastatin (Zocor), Pravastatin (Pravachol)); Ezetimibe (Zetia)
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has taken this medication in the 14 days prior to this most recent admission / presentation

Section: MEDICATION PRIOR TO THIS HOSPITALIZATION
Question: Anti-reflux or other GI medications
Definition: This refers to any substance used in the treatment gastric reflux by preventing the backward flow of stomach acid contents into the esophagus, or other drugs taken for ailments of the gastrointestinal system. Examples include: Proton Pump Inhibitors (Omeprazole (Prilosec), Pantoprazole (Protonix), Esomeprazole (Nexium), Lansoprazole (Prevacid)); H2-Receptor Antagonists (Ranitidine (Zantac), Famotidine (Pepcid))
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has taken this medication in the 14 days prior to this most recent admission / presentation

Section: MEDICATION PRIOR TO THIS HOSPITALIZATION
Question: Antidepressants and Anxiolytics
Definition: Antidepressants refers to mood-stimulating drugs used primarily in the treatment of affective disorders and related conditions. Anxiolytics refers to drugs used to treat anxiety disorders. Examples include: Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (Sertraline (Zoloft), Citalopram (Celexa), Fluoxetine (Prozac), Escitalopram (Lexapro)); Serotonin-Norepinephrine Reuptake Inhibitors (Venlafaxine (Effexor), Duloxetine (Cymbalta)); Benzodiazepines (Lorazepam (Ativan), Diazepam (Valium), Alprazolam (Xanax))
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has taken this medication in the 14 days prior to this most recent admission / presentation

Section: MEDICATION PRIOR TO THIS HOSPITALIZATION
Question: Antiepileptics
Definition: This refers to any substance used stop, prevent, or control seizures (convulsions). Examples include: Levetiracetam (Keppra), Valproate (Depakote), Carbamazepine (Tegretol), Lamotrigine (Lamictal).
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has taken this medication in the 14 days prior to this most recent admission / presentation

Section: MEDICATION PRIOR TO THIS HOSPITALIZATION
Question: Herbal or traditional treatment
Definition: Herbal or traditional treatment refers to herbs, herbal materials, herbal preparations and finished herbal products, that contain as active ingredients parts of plants, and other knowledge, skills, and practices based on the theories, beliefs, and experiences indigenous to different cultures that are used to treat physical or mental illness.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has taken a 'Herbal or traditional treatment in the 14 days prior to this most recent admission / presentation

Section: SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: Indicate if experienced at any time from onset of this illness to the day of presentation.
Question: Systemic / general symptoms
Definition: This refers to systemic / general / non-specific signs and symptoms
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at any time from onset of this illness to presentation.

Section: SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: Indicate if experienced at any time from onset of this illness to the day of presentation.
Question: Fever
Definition: Defined as the sensation of elevated body temperature without formal measurement, or a measured body temperature greater or equal to 38-degrees Celsius (38°C) or 100.4-Fahrenheit (100.4°F).
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during the date of assessment.

Section: SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: Indicate if experienced at any time from onset of this illness to the day of presentation.
Question: Chills or rigors
Definition: Defined as severe chills with violent shivering. A rigor is an episode of shaking or exaggerated shivering which can occur with a high fever.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at any time from onset of this illness to presentation.

Section: SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: Indicate if experienced at any time from onset of this illness to the day of presentation.
Question: Night sweats
Definition: This refers to perspiration experienced nocturnally that is unrelated to environmental temperature.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during the date of assessment.

Section: SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: Indicate if experienced at any time from onset of this illness to the day of presentation.
Question: Cold sweats
Definition: This refers to sweats accompanied by sensation of feeling cold, different from sweats caused by heat or exertion.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during the date of assessment.

Section: SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: Indicate if experienced at any time from onset of this illness to the day of presentation.
Question: Excessive sweating (hyperhidrosis)
Definition: This refers to excessive sweating that's not always related to heat or exercise.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during the date of assessment.

Section: SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: Indicate if experienced at any time from onset of this illness to the day of presentation.
Question: Restlessness
Definition: Defined as the inability to rest, relax or be still. A state of unease characterized by diffuse motor activity or motion subject to limited control, nonproductive or disorganized behaviour, and subjective distress.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during the date of assessment.

Section: SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: Indicate if experienced at any time from onset of this illness to the day of presentation.
Question: Fatigue / malaise / lethargy
Definition: Defined as the constellation of non-specific sensations: the feeling of tiredness characterised by a lack of energy or motivation; general discomfort or uneasiness; disinterestedness, listlessness, and indifference, resulting in difficulty performing simple tasks or concentrating.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at any time from onset of this illness to presentation.
Metathesaurus: C0015672, Fatigue | C0231218, Malaise  | C0023380 Lethargy

Section: SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: Indicate if experienced at any time from onset of this illness to the day of presentation.
Question: Weight loss
Definition: Defined as the reduction in total body weight that has occurred since the onset of this illness and has been unintentional or not attributable to active dieting, exercise or dedicated medication based weight-loss interventions. This can include patient-reported weight loss with or without objective measurements of weight.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at any time from onset of this illness to presentation.

Section: SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: Indicate if experienced at any time from onset of this illness to the day of presentation.
Question: Loss of smell / anosmia
Definition: This refers to patient reported and/or clinician-diagnosed inability of the patient to perceive odours
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during the date of assessment.

Section: SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: Indicate if experienced at any time from onset of this illness to the day of presentation.
Question: Loss of taste / ageusia
Definition: This refers to patient reported and/or clinician-diagnosed loss of taste function of the tongue.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during the date of assessment.

Section: SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: Indicate if experienced at any time from onset of this illness to the day of presentation.
Question: Feeling dizzy / faint
Definition: This refers to the subjective feeling of light-headedness or dizziness which may precede an episode of syncope or a sensation of unsteadiness, spinning or rocking.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at any time from onset of this illness to presentation.

Section: SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: Indicate if experienced at any time from onset of this illness to the day of presentation.
Question: Muscle aches / myalgia
Definition: Defined as pain localised to a muscle or group of muscles.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at any time from onset of this illness to presentation.

Section: SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: Indicate if experienced at any time from onset of this illness to the day of presentation.
Question: Joint pain / arthralgia
Definition: Defined as a sensation of marked discomfort or pain localised to one or more joints, including small and big joints.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at any time from onset of this illness to presentation.

Section: SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: Indicate if experienced at any time from onset of this illness to the day of presentation.
Question: Skin rash
Definition: Defined as any change in the skin which affects its appearance or texture. A rash may be localized to one part of the body or affect all the skin. Rashes may cause the skin to change colour, itch, become warm, bumpy, dry, cracked, or blistered, swell and may be painful.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at any time from onset of this illness to presentation.

Question: Cough
Definition: This refers to the presence of a cough and its characteristics. A productive cough refers to a cough accompanied by expectorated secretions (phlegm or mucus), while a non-productive cough refers to one which is not accompanied by expectorated secretions. Haemoptysis refers to the presence of blood or blood-streaked sputum from the respiratory tract.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at any time from onset of this illness to presentation.

Definition: This refers to the type of cough. A productive cough refers to a cough accompanied by expectorated secretions (phlegm or mucus)

This can include epistaxis (blood from nose), gingival bleeding (blood from gums/gingiva), blood from any part of the gastrointestinal tract (gastrointestinal bleeding) or genitourinary tracts (vagina or urethra) including hematuria.

Question: Specify bleeding / haemorrhage site(s)
Answer Options: 1, Skin | 7, Petechiae | 2, Nose | 3, Gums | 4, GI tract | 5, Urinary tract | 6, Vagina | 99, Unknown | 88, Other(s)
Definition: This refers to the location of bleeding/haemorrhage site(s). Petechiae refer to small reddish or purplish spots in skin or mucous membrane as a result of localised haemorrhage. Nose bleeding refers to haemorrhage localized in the nose. Gum bleeding refers to haemorrhage affecting the gingiva. Gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding refers to haemorrhage in any segment of the gastrointestinal tract from oesophagus to rectum. Urinary tract bleeding refers to haemorrhage originating from any part of the urinary system. Vaginal bleeding refers to haemorrhage originating from vagina, unrelated to normal menstruation.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option(s) corresponding to the location of bleeding/haemorrhage site(s).
Standardized Term Code: 297968009, Bleeding skin | 271813007 Petechiae | 249366005, Bleeding from nose | 86276007, Bleeding gums | 74474003, Gastrointestinal haemorrhage |34436003, blood in urine | 289530006, Bleeding from vagina
Metathesaurus: C0574741, Bleeding skin | C3808808, Epistaxis | C0017565, Gingival haemorrrhage | C0017181, Gastrointestinal haemorrhage |C3805433, haematuria | C0566961, Fresh bleeding from vagina

Question: Ascites

Question: Hepatomegaly

Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at any time from onset of this illness to presentation.

Question: Jaundice
Definition: Defined as a clinical manifestation of hyperbilirubinemia, characterized by the yellowish staining of the skin, mucous membrane and/or sclera.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at any time from onset of this illness to presentation.

Question: Melaena (dark tarry faeces with blood)
Definition: This refers to abnormally dark tarry feces containing blood, usually from gastrointestinal bleeding.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at any time from onset of this illness to presentation.

Section: SIGNS ON ADMISSION: Indicate if experienced at any time from onset of this illness to the day of presentation.
Question: Haematochezia (faeces with fresh blood)
Definition: This refers to the presence of blood in stool. It is the result of gastrointestinal hemorrhage and it may be easily seen in stool or may be identified microscopically.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at any time from onset of this illness to presentation.

Question: Rectal bleeding

Question: Reduced urine output

Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at any time from onset of this illness to presentation.

Question: Anaemia
Definition: This refers to a reduction in the number of red blood cells, the amount of hemoglobin, and/or the volume of packed red blood cells. Common manifestations include pallor, fatigue, dizziness, shortness of breath, and tachycardia.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at any time from onset of this illness to presentation.

Section: SIGNS ON ADMISSION: Indicate if experienced at any time from onset of this illness to the day of presentation.
Question: Neck stiffness
Definition: Defined as a sensation of tightness in the neck when attempting to move it, especially after a period of inactivity. Neck stiffness often involves soreness and difficulty moving the neck, especially when trying to turn the head to the side.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at any time from onset of this illness to presentation.

Section: SIGNS ON ADMISSION: Indicate if experienced at any time from onset of this illness to the day of presentation.
Question: Bulging fontanelle
Definition: This refers to the membranous areas between cranial bones in a newborn that appear elevated or full.

Question: Retro-orbital pain

Question: Hemiplegia
Definition: This refers to severe or complete loss of motor function on one side of the body; often caused by brain diseases that are localized to the cerebral hemisphere opposite to the side of weakness; less frequently, brain stem lesions; cervical spinal cord diseases, peripheral nervous system diseases, and other conditions may manifest as hemiplegia.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at any time from onset of this illness to presentation.

Section: SIGNS ON ADMISSION: Indicate if experienced at any time from onset of this illness to the day of presentation.
Question: Cognitive impairment
Definition: This refers to diminished or impaired mental and/or intellectual function.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at any time from onset of this illness to presentation.

Section: SIGNS ON ADMISSION: Indicate if experienced at any time from onset of this illness to the day of presentation.
Question: Psychological disturbance
Definition: This refers to the presence of signs or symptoms that affect an individual's thoughts, emotions, behaviours or mental well-being. The presence of psychological disturbances should be identified through a Mental Status Examination (MSE) or equivalent tool.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at any time from onset of this illness to presentation.

Section: SIGNS ON ADMISSION: Indicate if experienced at any time from onset of this illness to the day of presentation.
Question: Speech disturbance
Definition: This refers to difficulties with speech and communication that may result from pathologies in the brain.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at any time from onset of this illness to presentation.

Section: SIGNS ON ADMISSION: Indicate if experienced at any time from onset of this illness to the day of presentation.
Question: Cerebellar signs
Definition: Refers to the presence of a constellation of neurological signs typically indicate cerebellar dysfunction. Signs include dysdiadochokinesia, dysmetria, ataxia, nystagmus, intention tremor, slurred or scanning speech, hypotonia.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at any time from onset of this illness to presentation.

Section: PREGNANCY DETAILS
Question: Pregnant
Definition: This refers to women who reports to be pregnant at presentation and/or have had a positive pregnancy test in recent days prior to presentation.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient is pregnant at presentation. If the patient is of fertile age with no negative pregnancy test select 'Unknown'.

Section: PREGNANCY DETAILS
Question: Post-partum (within 6 weeks of delivery)
Definition: This refers to the temporal period relating to mother from completion of labour until six weeks post-delivery.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient is in post-partum period (within 6 weeks of delivery).

Section: PREGNANCY DETAILS
Question: Gestational weeks at presentation
Definition: This refers to the gestational age of the foetus (written in weeks). It can be calculated from the woman's last menstrual period (LMP) or calculated using the best obstetrical estimated due date (EDD) based on the following formula: Gestational Age = (280 - (EDD - Reference Date)). The reference date is the date in which you are trying to determine the gestational age.
Completion Guideline: Indicate the estimated gestational age of the foetus (in weeks).

Section: PREGNANCY DETAILS
Question: Delivery during this admission?
Definition: This refers to delivery of the foetus during the current admission.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the foetus was delivered during the curent admission.

Section: PREGNANCY DETAILS
Question: Was the patient pregnant within <= 21 days of symptom onset?
Definition: If non-pregnant currently, this refers to whether the patient was pregnant within 21 days of onset of symptoms.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes, if the patient was pregnant within 21 days of onset of symptoms.

Section: PREGNANCY DETAILS
Question: Was the patient pregnant within 22-42 days from admission?
Definition: If non-pregnant currently, this refers to whether the patient was pregnant wiithin 22-42 days from date of admission.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes, if the patient was pregnant wiithin 22-42 days from date of admission.

Question: Gestational outcome

Definition: This refers to the gestational age (GA) of the infant at delivery. Pre-term refers to an infant born before 37 weeks and 0 days gestational age.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Term birth' if gestational age (GA) at delivery >= 37 weeks and 'Preterm birth' if GA at delivery < 37 weeks.

Completion Guideline: Indicate the breastfeeding status of infant.

Section: PREGNANCY DETAILS
Question: Medically assisted reproduction?
Definition: This refers to medical procedures used primarily to address infertility.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the medically assisted reproduction techniques were involved to conceive the current pregnancy.

Section: PREGNANCY DETAILS
Question: Estimated date of delivery (EDD)
Definition: This refers to the expected date on which a pregnant woman will give birth. If not available, provide LMP below if possible
Completion Guideline: Indicate the estimated date of delivery.

Section: PREGNANCY DETAILS
Question: Date of last menstrual period (LMP)
Definition: This refers to the date of the first day of the most recent menstrual cycle.
Completion Guideline: Indicate the LMP.

Section: PREGNANCY DETAILS
Question: Parity
Definition: This refers to the number of pregnancies reaching 20 weeks and 0 days of gestation or beyond, regardless of the number of fetuses or outcomes.
Completion Guideline: Indicate the parity.

Section: PREGNANCY DETAILS
Question: Gravidity
Definition: This refer to a number of pregnancies, including current pregnancy, a woman has been in the past, irrespective of the pregnancy outcome.
Completion Guideline: Indicate the gravidity.

Section: PREGNANCY DETAILS
Question: Number of previous surgical (caesarean section) deliveries.
Definition: This refers to the number of previous surgical deliveries of one or more intrauterine fetuses though an abdominal incision (cesaerian section).
Completion Guideline: Indicate the number of previous surgical (caesarean section) deliveries.

Section: PREGNANCY DETAILS
Question: Number of embryos/foetuses in this pregnancy.
Definition: This refers to the number of embryos/fetuses in this pregnancy
Completion Guideline: Indicate the number of embryos/fetuses in this pregnancy.

Section: PREGNANCY DETAILS
Question: Is the patient in labour at presentation?
Definition: Labour refers to uterine contractions resulting in cervical change (dilation and/or effacement) to facilitate the explusion of intrauterine contents of gestation, including the feotus and placenta.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the pregnant patient is in labour at presentation.

Section: PREGNANCY DETAILS
Question: Former smoker (stopped prior to current pregnancy)
Definition: This refers to a person who has quit smoking prior to conception of the current pregnancy but has smoked at least 100 of the above items in their life.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this condition exists in the current pregnancy.

Section: PREGNANCY DETAILS
Question: Former smoker (stopped during current pregnancy)
Definition: This refers to a person who quit smoking after conception of the current pregnancy but has smoked at least 100 of the above items in their life.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this condition exists in the current pregnancy.

Section: PREGNANCY DETAILS
Question: Substance use during pregnancy
Definition: This refers to maternal administration of any chemical agent with local or systemic distribution that causes maternal and/or fetal adverse side effects
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this condition exists in the current pregnancy.

Section: PREGNANCY-RELATED COMPLICATIONS
Question: Maternal pregnancy complications?
Definition: This refers to maternal medical complications that arise during pregnancy.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if other comorbidities, not listed above, exists in the current pregnancy.

Section: PREGNANCY-RELATED COMPLICATIONS
Question: Pre-eclampsia
Definition: This refers to a systolic blood pressure of 140 mmHg or higher, or a diastolic blood pressure of 90 mmHg or higher on two occasions at least 4 hours apart (or greater than or equal to 160/110 mmHg within a short interval) after 20 weeks of gestation in a woman with previously normal blood pressure. It may present with proteinuria but if not, it may be associated with thrombocytopenia, impaired liver function, progressive renal insufficiency, pulmonary oedema, or new-onset cerebral or visual disturbances.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this condition exists in the current pregnancy.

Section: PREGNANCY-RELATED COMPLICATIONS
Question: Eclampsia
Definition: This refers to a potentially life-threatening pregnancy-related disorder characterized by tonic-clonic seizures in association with hypertension after the twentieth week of gestation and up to six weeks postpartum and in the absence of other potential causes of seizures.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this condition exists in the current pregnancy.

Section: PREGNANCY-RELATED COMPLICATIONS
Question: HELLP
Definition: This refers to severe preeclampsia associated with any of the following findings: thrombocytopenia (platelets less than 100,000 per microliter), impaired liver function (twice normal elevation of hepatic transaminases; severe, persistent right upper quadrant or epigastric pain), progressive renal insufficiency (serum creatinine greater than 1.1 mg/dL or doubling of baseline in the absence of other renal disease), pulmonary oedema, or new-onset cerebral or visual disturbances.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this condition exists in the current pregnancy.

Section: PREGNANCY-RELATED COMPLICATIONS
Question: Gestational diabetes
Definition: This refers to glucose intolerance first diagnosed during pregnancy.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this condition exists in the current pregnancy.

Section: PREGNANCY-RELATED COMPLICATIONS
Question: Pregnancy-induced hypertension
Definition: This refers to blood pressure elevation after 20 weeks of gestation in the absence of either proteinuria or systemic findings like thrombocytopenia, impaired liver function, progressive renal insufficiency, pulmonary oedema or the new-onset of cerebral or visual disturbances.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this condition exists in the current pregnancy.

Section: PREGNANCY-RELATED COMPLICATIONS
Question: Uterine bleeding
Definition: This refers to a disorder characterized by bleeding from the uterus.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this condition exists in the current pregnancy.

Section: PREGNANCY-RELATED COMPLICATIONS
Question: Other maternal pregnancy complication(s)
Definition: This refers to other maternal pregnancy complcations, not specified above, present in the current pregnancy.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this condition exists in the current pregnancy.

Section: PREGNANCY-RELATED COMPLICATIONS
Question: Specify other maternal pregnancy complication(s)
Definition: This refers to other maternal pregnancy complcations, not specified above, present in the current pregnancy.
Completion Guideline: If 'Yes', list any other maternal pregnancy complications, not specified above, present in the current pregnancy.

Section: PREGNANCY-RELATED COMPLICATIONS
Question: Placental / amniotic fluid / foetal abnormalities identified antenatally
Definition: This refers to placental / amniotic / foetal complications that arise during pregnancy.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if other comorbidities, not listed above, exists in the current pregnancy.

Section: PREGNANCY-RELATED COMPLICATIONS
Question: Diminished amniotic fluid
Definition: This refers to lower than normal quantity of amniotic fluid in the amniotic sac as compared to normal values. Typically associated with an amniotic fluid index (AFI) of less than 5 cm or a single maximum vertical pocket (MVP) of less than 2 cm.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this condition exists in the current pregnancy.

Section: PREGNANCY-RELATED COMPLICATIONS
Question: Excessive amniotic fluid
Definition: This refers to an excess quantity of amniotic fluid in the amniotic sac as compared to normal values. Typically associated with an amniotic fluid index (AFI) of greater than or equal to 25 cm or a single maximum vertical pocket (MVP) of greater than 8 cm.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this condition exists in the current pregnancy.

Section: PREGNANCY-RELATED COMPLICATIONS
Question: Placenta previa
Definition: This refers to a condition in which the placenta covers or is within 1 cm of the cervical os.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this condition exists in the current pregnancy.

Section: PREGNANCY-RELATED COMPLICATIONS
Question: Low-lying placenta
Definition: This refers to a condition in which the placental edge is within 2 cm of but not covering the cervical os.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this condition exists in the current pregnancy.

Section: PREGNANCY-RELATED COMPLICATIONS
Question: Placental insufficiency
Definition: This refer to failure of the placenta to deliver an adequate supply of nutrients and oxygen to the foetus.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this condition exists in the current pregnancy.

Section: PREGNANCY-RELATED COMPLICATIONS
Question: Intrauterine growth restriction
Definition: This refers to abnormal restriction of fetal growth with fetal weight below the tenth percentile for gestational age.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this condition exists in the current pregnancy.

Section: PREGNANCY-RELATED COMPLICATIONS
Question: Other placental / amniotic fluid / foetal abnormalities identified antenatally
Definition: This refers to other placental / amniotic / foetal  complcations, not specified above, present in the current pregnancy.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this condition exists in the current pregnancy.

Section: PREGNANCY-RELATED COMPLICATIONS
Question: specify other placental / amniotic fluid / foetal abnormalities identified antenatally
Definition: This refers to other placental / amniotic / foetal  complcations, not specified above, present in the current pregnancy.
Completion Guideline: If 'Yes', list any other placental / amniotic / foetal complications, not specified above, present in the current pregnancy.

Section: PREGNANCY-RELATED COMPLICATIONS
Question: Malaria infection in pregnancy
Definition: This refers to maternal malaria infection during pregnancy, childbirth or the puerperium.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this condition exists in the current pregnancy.

Definition: This refers to the specific biological samples tested during pregnancy.

Section: PREGNANCY-RELATED TESTING
Question: Which of the following samples were taken?
Answer Options: 1, Amniotic fluid | 2, Placenta | 3, Cord blood | 4, Vaginal swab | 5, Faecal/rectal swab | 6, Pregnancy tissue | 99, Unknown | 88, Other
Definition: This refers to the specific samples tested during pregnancy. Amniotic fluid sample refers to a small sample of the clear or slightly yellow fluid that surrounds and protects an unborn baby during pregnancy. Placenta sample refers to a tissue biopsy taken from the placenta. Cord blood refers to a blood sample taken from the umbilical cord. Vaginal swab refers to collection of cells and mucus samples from the vagina. Rectal swab refers to collection of cells and mucus samples from the rectum.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option(s) which represent the samples tested during the pregnancy.
Standardized Term Code: 119373006, Amniotic fluid specimen (specimen) | 122736005, Tissue specimen from placenta (specimen) | 122556008, Cord blood specimen (specimen) | 258520000, Vaginal swab (specimen) | 258528007, Rectal swab (specimen)

Section: PREGNANCY-RELATED TESTING
