Definition: This refers to the specific samples tested during pregnancy. Amniotic fluid sample refers to a small sample of the clear or slightly yellow fluid that surrounds and protects an unborn baby during pregnancy. Placenta sample refers to a tissue biopsy taken from the placenta. Cord blood refers to a blood sample taken from the umbilical cord. Vaginal swab refers to collection of cells and mucus samples from the vagina. Rectal swab refers to collection of cells and mucus samples from the rectum.
Completion Guideline: Give a description of the sample testing and results.

Section: PREGNANCY OUTCOME
Question: Pregnancy outcome
Answer Options: 1, Livebirth (even if infant died after birth) | 2, Miscarriage (<22 weeks) | 3, Termination by choice | 4, Termination - ultrasound abnormality | 5, Termination - other/unknown reason | 6, Stillbirth (intra-uterine / intrapartum death from 22 gest weeks) | 7, Ectopic pregnancy | 8, Ongoing  | 99, Unknown | 88, Other
Definition: This refers to the outcome of previous conception and ensuing pregnancy. Livebirth refers to a foetus born alive with heartbeats or respiration regardless of gestaional age or subsequent death after birth. Stillbirth refers to death of the fetus in-utero after at least 22 weeks of gestation. Termination of pregnancy refers to intentional removal of a foetus from the uterus using medical and / or surgical procedures. Neonatal death refers to death within the first 28 days of life.
Completion Guideline: Indicate the outcome of the previous pregnancy.
Metathesaurus: C0032972, Pregnancy Outcome | 1, C0419373 Livebirth | 2, C0595939 Stillbirth | 4, C4552766 Miscarriage | 3, C0392535 Termination of pregnancy

Section: PREGNANCY OUTCOME
Question: Gestational weeks at pregnancy outcome
Definition: This refers to the gestational age (in weeks) at the pregnancy outcome (livebirth / stillbirth / miscarriage / termination of pregnancy).
Completion Guideline: Indicate the estimated gestational age in weeks.

Section: PREGNANCY OUTCOME
Question: Baby tested for mother's infection of interest?
Definition: This refers to testing the baby for the mother's infection of interest.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if the baby was tested for the mother's infection of interest.

Section: PREGNANCY OUTCOME
Question: Specify test result from mother's infection of interest
Definition: This refers to the result of testing the baby for the mother's infection of interest.
Completion Guideline: Indicate the test result.

Section: PREGNANCY OUTCOME
Question: If termination for ultrasound abnormality or other reason, specify
Definition: This refers to the indication for termination of pregnancy.
Completion Guideline: If ultrasound abnormality or other, specify the indication for termination of pregnancy.

Section: PREGNANCY OUTCOME
Question: If stillbirth: macerated or fresh?
Definition: Macerated stillbirth refers to a foetus that died in the womb before labor began and shows signs of tissue and skin changes. Fresh stillbirth refers to a foetus shows=ing no signs of maceration or degenerative changes at the time of delivery.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option which represent the type of sillbirth.

Section: PREGNANCY OUTCOME
Question: Did mother die in pregnancy?
Definition: This refers to death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of the end of the pregnancy, irrespective of the duration or anatomic site of the pregnancy, due to any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management, but not from accidental or incidental causes.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this condition exists in the current pregnancy.

Section: PREGNANCY OUTCOME
Question: Age at death
Definition: This refers to age of the mother at the time of death (in years).
Completion Guideline: Specify the age of the mother at the time of death (in years).

Section: PREGNANCY OUTCOME
Question: Cause(s) of death
Definition: This refers to  circumstance(s) or condition(s) that results in the death of the mother.
Completion Guideline: Specify the circumstance(s) or condition(s) that results in the death of the mother.

Section: PREGNANCY OUTCOME
Question: Place of death
Definition: This refers to the facility where the maternal death occurred.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option which represents the facility where the maternal death occurred.

Section: PREGNANCY OUTCOME
Question: Death timepoint
Answer Options: 1, Pre-delivery | 2, During delivery | 3, Post-delivery (within 40 days) | 99, Unknown
Definition: This refers to the timepoint of maternal death relative to the time of delivery of the foetus.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option which represents the timepoint of maternal death relative to the time of delivery of the foetus.

Section: PREGNANCY OUTCOME
Question: Other details about pregnancy, not specified above.
Definition: This refers to other details about the pregnancy (about pregnancy losses, termination etc if available), not specified above.
Completion Guideline: Indicate any other details about the pregnancy (about pregnancy losses, termination etc if available), not specified above.

Completion Guideline: Indicate the participant identification number allocated to the newborn in the study.

Section: NEONATE DETAILS
Question: Mode of delivery
Answer Options: 1, Vaginal | 2, Assisted vaginal | 3, Elective caesarean | 99, Unknown
Definition: This refers to the method by which a foetus is delivered.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option that represents the method by which a foetus is delivered.

Section: NEONATE DETAILS
Question: If elective caesarean: What was the timing?
Answer Options: 1, Before labour, before rupture of membranes | 2, After labour and/or rupture of membranes | 99, Unknown
Definition: This refers to the timing of elective caeserean section delivery.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option that represents the timing of elective caeserean section delivery..

Section: NEONATE DETAILS
Question: Place of delivery
Definition: This refers to the place of delivery of the foetus.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option that represents the place of delivery of the foetus.

Section: NEONATE DETAILS
Question: Gestational age
Definition: This refers to the gestational age of the foetus (written in completed weeks). It can be calculated from the woman's last menstrual period (LMP) or calculated using the best obstetrical estimated due date (EDD) based on the following formula: Gestational Age = (280 - (EDD - Reference Date)). The reference date is the date in which you are trying to determine the gestational age.
Completion Guideline: Indicate the estimated gestational age of the foetus (in weeks).

Section: NEONATE DETAILS
Question: How was gestation estimated?
Definition: This refers to the method of estimating the gestational age. LMP refers to the date of the first day of the most recent menstrual cycle. EDD refers to the estiamted date of delivery.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option that represents the method used to estimate gestational age.

Section: NEONATE DETAILS
Question: Newborn length at birth
Definition: This refers to the measurement of a newborn's length from the top of their head to the bottom of one of their heels
Completion Guideline: Indicate the neonate's birth length (in cm).

Section: NEONATE DETAILS
Question: Head circumference at birth
Definition: This refers to the measurement of the largest area of the head (distance from around the back of the head to above the eyebrows and ears) (in cm).
Completion Guideline: Indicate the neonate's birth head circumference (in cm).

Section: NEONATE DETAILS
Question: APGAR score at 5 mins (1-10)
Definition: This refers to a score to evaluate a newborn's adjustment to extrauterine life. Five items - heart rate, respiratory effort, muscle tone, reflex irritability, and color - are evaluated 60 seconds after birth and again five minutes later on a scale from 0-2, 0 being the lowest, 2 being normal. The five numbers are added for the Apgar score. A score of 0-3 represents severe distress, 4-7 indicates moderate distress, and a score of 7-10 predicts an absence of difficulty in adjusting to extrauterine life.
Completion Guideline: Indicate the neonate's APGAR score at 5 minutes.

Section: NEONATE DETAILS
Question: Resuscitation required following delivery
Definition: This refers to measures applied for the restoration of life to a newborn.
Completion Guideline: Indicate whether neonatal resuscitation was required following delivery.

Section: NEONATE DETAILS
Question: Give details
Definition: This refers to measures applied for the restoration of life to a newborn.
Completion Guideline: Specify the details of the neonatal resuscitation

Section: DAILY ASSESSMENT
Question: DATE OF ASSESSMENT
Definition: This indicates the day of data collection and sampling (may not be the date of completion). This may be retrospective information at the time of discharge (transfer to other hospital or dead in hospital).
Completion Guideline: Enter the date. Use the format DD/MM/YYYY.

Section: DAILY ASSESSMENT
Question: Current level of care
Answer Options: 1, Outpatient | 2, Admitted to normal ward for isolation only | 3, Admitted to normal ward for clinical care | 4, High dependency |  5, Intensive care admission
Definition: Refers to the level of care on date of assessment.
Completion Guideline: Select the highest level of care on the date of assessment.
Metathesaurus: C4545175, Outpatient care management | C0583229, Admission to ward | C1301858, Admission to high dependency unit | C0583239, Admission to intensive care unit

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Enter Vital Signs data for this date?
Definition: This refers to vital signs data recorded for this date.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if you want to record vital sign data for this day of assessment. If 'Yes', for the following questions unless otherwise specified, Record the value furthest from the normal physiological range recorded between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment. Results that were rejected by the clinical team should not be included.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Highest temperature (select units)
Definition: Refers to the highest peripheral body temperature (rectal if <3 months) between 00:00 and 24:00 on day of assessment.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate units for temperature.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Highest temperature (°C)
Definition: Refers to the highest peripheral body temperature (rectal if <3 months) in degrees Celsius (°C) between 00:00 and 24:00 on day of assessment.
Completion Guideline: Enter the highest peripheral body temperature (°C) recorded between 00:00 and 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Highest temperature (°F)
Definition: Refers to the highest peripheral body temperature (rectal if <3 months) in degrees Fahrenheit (°F) between 00:00 and 24:00 on day of assessment.
Completion Guideline: Enter the highest peripheral body temperature (°F) recorded between 00:00 and 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: HR (beats/minute)
Definition: Refers to heart rate measured in beats per minute. This may be measured manually or by electronic monitoring.
Completion Guideline: Enter the heart rate measured in beats per minute. Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: RR (bpm)
Definition: Refers to respiratory rate in breaths per minute. Manual rather than electronic measurement is preferred where possible (this is achieved by counting the number of breaths for one minute, counting how many times the chest rises within this time period).  If both abnormal low and high rate observed, record the abnormally high rate.
Completion Guideline: Enter the respiratory rate measured in breaths per minute. Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment. If both abnormal low and high rate observed, record the abnormally high rate.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Systolic BP (mmHg)
Definition: This refers to the systolic blood pressure from the observation with the lowest mean arterial pressure (if mean arterial pressure has not been calculated, report the measurement with lowest systolic blood pressure).  For example, if the blood pressure is 120/85 mmHg, enter 120 in the section marked 'systolic BP'.
Completion Guideline: Enter the systolic blood pressure measured in millimetres of mercury (mmHg). Record the systolic blood pressure from the observation with the lowest mean arterial pressure (MAP) (if mean arterial pressure has not been calculated, report the measurement with lowest systolic blood pressure) that occurred between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Diastolic BP (mmHg)
Definition: This refers to the diastolic blood pressure from the observation with the lowest mean arterial pressure (if mean arterial pressure has not been calculated, report the measurement with lowest systolic blood pressure). For example, if the blood pressure is 120/85 mmHg, enter 85 in the section marked 'diastolic BP'.
Completion Guideline: Enter the diastolic blood pressure measured in millimetres of mercury (mmHg). Record the diastolic blood pressure from the observation with the lowest mean arterial pressure (MAP) (if mean arterial pressure has not been calculated, report the measurement with lowest systolic blood pressure) that occurred between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Mean arterial blood pressure (mmHg)
Definition: Mean arterial blood pressure (MAP) may be directly measured (via intra-arterial catheter) or be approximated without an invasive procedure using the following formula: diastolic pressure plus 1/3 of the pulse pressure, where pulse pressure is systolic pressure - diastolic pressure.
Completion Guideline: Enter the lowest recorded MAP that occurred between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Oxygen saturation at room air (no oxygen support) (%)
Definition: This refers to the measurement of the ratio of oxygenated hemoglobin to total hemoglobin in the blood, measured at room air with no oxygen support.
Completion Guideline: Indicate the measurement of oxygen saturation at room air with no oxygen support.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: How was oxygen saturation at room air measured?
Answer Options: 1, Pulse Oximetry | 2, Arterial blood gas measurement | 88, Other | 99, Unknown
Definition: This refers to the method of measurement of oxygen saturation.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option which represents the method of measurement of oxygen saturation.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Supplemental oxygen?
Definition: This refers to the delivery of supplemental oxygen at the time of the above, lowest SpO2 (%), recording.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the FiO2 was measured along-side the lowest oxygen saturation (SpO2) reported above.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Answer Options: 1, Nasal Prongs | 2, Face mask | 3, High flow nasal oxygen | 4, Non-invasive ventilation | 5, Invasive ventilation | 6, ECMO / ECLS | 99, Unknown
Definition: This refers to the type / mode of delivery for supplemental oxygen at the time of the above, lowest SpO2 (%), recording.
Completion Guideline: Select the most approproate option which represents the type / mode of delivery for supplemental oxygen at the time of the above, lowest SpO2 (%), recording.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Oxygen saturation with supplemental oxygen (%)
Definition: This refers to the oxygen saturation, that may be measured by pulse oximetry or by arterial blood gas analysis. It is irrespective of ventilation or supplemental oxygen requirement.
Completion Guideline: Enter the percentage oxygen saturation. Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: How was oxygen saturation with supplemental oxygen measured?
Answer Options: 1, Pulse Oximetry | 2, Arterial blood gas measurement | 88, Other | 99, Unknown
Definition: This refers to the method of measurement of oxygen saturation.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option which represents the method of measurement of oxygen saturation.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: FiO2 at time of lowest SpO2 (select units)
Definition: FiO2 can be reported as either a fraction or a percentage. Note that 0.21 and 21% are equivalent to the FiO2 of room-air.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate units for FiO2.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: FiO2 at time of lowest SpO2 (Fraction, 0.21-1.0)
Definition: This refers to the measured fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) delivered at the time of the above, lowest oxygen saturation (%), recording.
Completion Guideline: Enter the FiO2 (0.21-1.0) that was measured along-side the lowest oxygen saturation (SpO2) reported above.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: FiO2 at time of lowest SpO2 (%, 21-100)
Definition: This refers to the measured fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) delivered at the time of the above, lowest oxygen saturation (%), recording.
Completion Guideline: Enter the FiO2 (21-100%) that was measured along-side the lowest oxygen saturation (SpO2) reported above.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: FiO2 at time of lowest SpO2 (Highest L/min)
Definition: This refers to the measured fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) delivered at the time of the above, lowest oxygen saturation (%), recording.
Completion Guideline: Enter the FiO2 (L/min) that was measured along-side the lowest oxygen saturation (SpO2) reported above.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Capillary refill time >2 seconds
Definition: Capillary refill time is measured by pressing on the sternum for five seconds with a finger or thumb until the underlying skin turns white and then noting the time in seconds needed for the colour to return once the pressure is released.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the capillary refill time was greater than 2 seconds at any time between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: ACVPU
Definition: Refers to the scoring system for consciousness: alert; confused (new-onset or worsening); responding to voice; responding to pain; unresponsive.
Completion Guideline: Select the single option corresponding to the least responsive condition of the patient between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment. If the patient is being sedated on the day of assessment record the value before the sedation.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Glasgow Coma Score (GCS / 15)
Definition: The Glasgow Coma Scale is a scoring system for consciousness. It is scored out of 15 and requires an assessment of responsiveness to stimulus. Glasgow Coma Score: https://www.glasgowcomascale.org/downloads/GCS-Assessment-Aid-English.pdf?v=3
Completion Guideline: Enter the lowest GCS recorded between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment. For intubated patients and patients with a non-fenestrated tracheostomy, give 1 point for the voice component and calculate the total as usual. Suffixes such as 't' for tracheostomy cannot be entered on to the database. If the patient is sedated on the day of assessment these parameters should correspond to the values observed before sedation.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Richmond Agitation-Sedation Scale (RASS)
Definition: Richmond Agitation-Sedation Scale (RASS) is a medical scale used to measure the agitation or sedation level of a person. It ranges from -5 to +4, where 0 refers to an 'Alert and calm' patient that spontaneously pays attention.
Completion Guideline: If performed, enter the lowest value (between -5 and +4) between 00:00 to 24:00 hours on day of assessment.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Urine output (mL/24 hours)
Definition: This refers to the amount of urine the patient has produced over a 24-hour period, specifically the date of assessment. This may be measured e.g. via use of a urinary catheter or estimated.
Completion Guideline: Record the patient's urine output (in ml/24hours) over the day of assessment

Section: SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Enter patient reported symptoms data for this date?
Definition: This refers to signs and symptoms recorded o this date.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if you want to record signs and symptoms data for this day of assessment.

Section: SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Systemic / general symptoms
Definition: This refers to systemic / general / non-specific signs and symptoms
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Fever
Definition: Defined as the sensation of elevated body temperature without formal measurement, or a measured body temperature greater or equal to 38-degrees Celsius (38°C) or 100.4-Fahrenheit (100.4°F).
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Chills or rigors
Definition: Defined as severe chills with violent shivering. A rigor is an episode of shaking or exaggerated shivering which can occur with a high fever.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Night sweats
Definition: This refers to perspiration experienced nocturnally that is unrelated to environmental temperature.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Cold sweats
Definition: This refers to sweats accompanied by sensation of feeling cold, different from sweats caused by heat or exertion.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Excessive sweating (hyperhidrosis)
Definition: This refers to excessive sweating that's not always related to heat or exercise.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Fatigue / malaise / lethargy
Definition: Defined as the constellation of non-specific sensations: the feeling of tiredness characterised by a lack of energy or motivation; general discomfort or uneasiness; disinterestedness, listlessness, and indifference, resulting in difficulty performing simple tasks or concentrating.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Metathesaurus: C0015672, Fatigue | C0231218, Malaise  | C0023380 Lethargy

Section: SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Restlessness
Definition: Defined as the inability to rest, relax or be still. A state of unease characterized by diffuse motor activity or motion subject to limited control, nonproductive or disorganized behaviour, and subjective distress.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Weight loss
Definition: Defined as the reduction in total body weight that has occurred since the onset of this illness and has been unintentional or not attributable to active dieting, exercise or dedicated medication-based weight-loss interventions. This can include patient-reported weight loss with or without objective measurements of weight.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Loss of smell / anosmia
Definition: This refers to patient reported and/or clinician-diagnosed inability of the patient to perceive odours
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Loss of taste / ageusia
Definition: This refers to patient reported and/or clinician-diagnosed loss of taste function of the tongue.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Question: Bleeding / haemorrhage
Definition: Defined as the presence of blood in a location in which it is not physiologically normal or loss of blood from the circulation, either internally or externally. This can include epistaxis (blood from nose), gingival bleeding (blood from gums/gingiva), blood from any part of the gastrointestinal tract (gastrointestinal bleeding) or genitourinary tracts (vagina or urethra) including hematuria.

Question: Specify bleeding / haemorrhage site(s)
Answer Options: 1, Skin | 7, Petechiae | 2, Nose | 3, Gums | 4, GI tract | 5, Urinary tract | 6, Vagina | 99, Unknown | 88, Other(s)
Definition: This refers to the location of bleeding/haemorrhage site(s). Petechiae refer to small reddish or purplish spots in skin or mucous membrane as a result of localised haemorrhage. Nose bleeding refers to haemorrhage localized in the nose. Gum bleeding refers to haemorrhage affecting the gingiva. Gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding refers to haemorrhage in any segment of the gastrointestinal tract from oesophagus to rectum. Urinary tract bleeding refers to haemorrhage originating from any part of the urinary system. Vaginal bleeding refers to haemorrhage originating from vagina, unrelated to normal menstruation.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option(s) corresponding to the location of bleeding/haemorrhage site(s).

Section: SKIN & MUCOSA ASSESSMENT: Record the information furthest from normal between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Enter Skin and Mucosa Assessment data for this date?
Definition: The following questions pertain to clinical inspection of skin lesions. Data recorded in this section should detail the conditions present on the date of assessment. This section should be completed for date of admission and any subsequent day as per the local protocol.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', to enter information pertaining to clinical inspection of skin lesions on the day of assessment.

Section: SKIN & MUCOSA ASSESSMENT: Record the information furthest from normal between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Rash distribution
Answer Options: 1, Generalised | 2, Localised around the genitals | 3, Centrifugal-more on the extremities | 4, Centripetal-more on the trunk | 88, Other distribution | 99, Unknown distribution
Definition: This refers to the pattern of distribution of the skin rash. Generalised rash refers to a widespread rash covering the entire surface of the skin. Centrifugal rash is concentrated on the distal extremities, with fewer lesions on the trunk. Centripetal rash is concentrated on the trunk, with fewer lesions on the extremities. Localised around the genitals refers to a rash concentrated around the skin on the genitals.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate pattern of distribution of the skin rash on the day of assessment.

Section: SKIN & MUCOSA ASSESSMENT: Record the information furthest from normal between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Specify other rash distribution
Definition: This refers to the pattern of distribution of the skin rash.
Completion Guideline: If 'Other', write the pattern of distribution of the skin rash on the day of assessment.

Section: SKIN & MUCOSA ASSESSMENT: Record the information furthest from normal between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Rash morphology
Answer Options: 1, Mostly discrete lesions | 2, Semi-confluent lesions | 3, Confluent lesions | 4, Mixed morphology | 99, Unknown
Definition: This refers to the predominant morphology of the skin rash. Discrete lesions refer to separate, distinct lesions that are not joined to one another. Confluent lesions refer to lesions that are joining or running together.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate morphology of the skin rash on the day of assessment.

Section: SKIN & MUCOSA ASSESSMENT: Record the information furthest from normal between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Rash size (skin) - widest diameter of any lesion
Definition: This refers to the size of the skin rash, recorded as the widest diameter of any lesion in centimetres (cm).
Completion Guideline: Indicate the widest diameter of any skin lesion measured in centimetres (cm) on the day of assessment.

Section: SKIN & MUCOSA ASSESSMENT: Record the information furthest from normal between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Current skin lesion status
Answer Options: 1, There are active skin lesions | 2, There are skin lesions and none of them are active (lesions in the process of healing & resolving, including scabbed lesions) | 3, All skin lesions have completely resolved (all scabs have fallen off with intact skin) | 4, No skin lesions have developed to date
Definition: This refers to the status of the skin lesions. Active skin lesions refer to macules (flat lesions), papules (raised lesions), vesicles (raised and filled with clear fluid) or pustules (raised and filed with pus, an opaque fluid) which can develop a depression in the centre (umbilication) or ulcerate. Skin lesions which are not active refer to those which have begun to crust (dry) over, in the process of healing & resolving, to form scabs (consisting of dried serum, blood, or pus). Skin lesions which have completely resolved refer to all scabs having fallen off, leaving intact underlying skin.
Completion Guideline: Indicate the most appropriate dermatological status of the skin lesions on the day of assessment.

Section: SKIN & MUCOSA ASSESSMENT: Record the information furthest from normal between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Is there residual evidence of resolved skin lesions (scar/discolouration)?
Definition: This refers to the presence of sequalae secondary to resolved or resolving skin lesions i.e. lesions that are no longer active (including scabbed lesions and lesions where all scabs have fallen off with intact skin). This can include scars or discoloration.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if there is residual evidence of resolved skin lesions on the day of assessment.

Section: SKIN & MUCOSA ASSESSMENT: Record the information furthest from normal between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Current mucosal lesion status
Answer Options: 1, There are mucosal lesions | 2, There is a history of mucosal lesions but none at present (all have resolved and mucosa is healed) | 3, No mucosal lesions have developed to date
Definition: This refers to the presence of mucosal membrane involvement. It includes the lining of the digestive tract, respiratory tract and genitourinary tract.
Completion Guideline: Select the single most appropriate option that represents the extent of mucosal involvement between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SKIN & MUCOSA ASSESSMENT: Record the information furthest from normal between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: If there are mucosal lesions: Persistent symptoms or signs of mucosal oropharyngeal lesions
Definition: This refers to the presence of mucosal membrane involvement in the oropharyngeal cavity, as evidenced by active mucosal lesions, erythema, inflammatory changes. Symptoms may include sore throat, painful ulcerations, painful or difficult swallowing.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient had symptoms of mucosal oropharyngeal lesions between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if there are active lesions involving this area between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Question: Type of head, face or neck lesions
Answer Options: 1, Vesicle | 2, Pustule | 3, Ulcerated lesions | 4, Necrotising lesions | 5, Fungating lesions | 6, Haemorrhagic lesions | 88, Other
Definition: This refers to the type of skin lesions involving the head, face or neck. Vesicle refers to raised lesion and filled with clear fluid. Pustule refers to raised lesion and filed with pus, an opaque fluid. Ulcerated lesion refers to a lesion with break in the skin. Necrotising lesion refers to a lesion with necrotic (dead) tissue. Fungating lesion refers to a lesion from underlying tissues which is breaking through the skin's surface.
Completion Guideline: Select the single most appropriate option that represents the type of lesions involving this area, between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Question: Inside mouth lesion status
Answer Options: 1, Causing pain | 2, Bleeding or Discharge | 3, Ulceration
Definition: This refers to the status of mucosal lesions in the mouth (oral cavity). A lesion causing pain is associated with an unpleasant, uncomfortable or painful sensation at the site of the lesion. A lesion which is bleeding or discharging is associated with bleeding from blood vessels or serous / purulent fluid discharge at the site of the lesion. An ulcerated lesion is associated with erosion of the mucous membrane of the mouth, showing local excavation of the surface at the site of the lesion.
Completion Guideline: Select the single most appropriate option that represents the type of lesions involving this area, between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: TREATMENTS & INTERVENTIONS: Record all interventions given between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Intravenous (parenteral) fluids
Definition: This refers to intravenous fluid which includes crystalloid, albumin, gelatin, starches or other solutions.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient received intravenous fluids between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on the day of assessment.

Section: TREATMENTS & INTERVENTIONS: Record all interventions given between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Intravenous fluid type
Definition: This refers to the type of parenteral or intravenous (IV) fluid is prescribed as a replacement of fluid, electrolytes, calories, vitamins, and other nutritional substances. Intravenous fluids may be crystalloids (commonly including 0.9% Sodium Chloride (Normal Saline), Lactated Ringer(USP), 0.45% Sodium Chloride (Half-normal saline), 0.45% normal saline + 4% Glucose (Half-normal saline with dextrose), 0.18%-0.3% Sodium Chloride + 4% Glucose (Hypotonic saline with dextrose), 5% Glucose (Dextrose 5% in Water), Ringeracetate or Plasmalyte) or colloids (commonly including gelatins, starches or albumin).
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option corresponding to the type of intravenous or parenteral fluid(s) administered.

Section: TREATMENTS & INTERVENTIONS: Record all interventions given between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Crystalloid volume (mL/24 hours)
Definition: Crystalloid fluids refer to aqueous solutions of mineral salts and other small, water-soluble molecules. They are commonly used for fluid resuscitation in the presence of hypovolemia, hemorrhage, sepsis, and dehydration Common crystalloids include 0.9% Sodium Chloride (Normal Saline), Lactated Ringer(USP), 0.45% Sodium Chloride (Half-normal saline), 0.45% normal saline + 4% Glucose (Half-normal saline with dextrose), 0.18%-0.3% Sodium Chloride + 4% Glucose (Hypotonic saline with dextrose), 5% Glucose (Dextrose 5% in Water), Ringeracetate or Plasmalyte.
Completion Guideline: Record the volume of crystalloid fluids the patient received between 00:00 and 24:00 on day of assessment in millilitres (mL).

Section: TREATMENTS & INTERVENTIONS: Record all interventions given between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Colloid volume (mL/24 hours)
Definition: Colloid fluids are solutions that contain large molecules, such as proteins or polysaccharides, which remain in the bloodstream for a longer duration compared to crystalloids. These fluids help maintain or expand intravascular volume by drawing water into the blood vessels via oncotic pressure. Common colloids include gelatins, starches or albumin.
Completion Guideline: Record the volume of colloid fluids the patient received between 00:00 and 24:00 on day of assessment in millilitres (mL).

Section: TREATMENTS & INTERVENTIONS: Record all interventions given between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Blood / blood products transfusion
Definition: This refers to a transfusion of blood (whole blood or packed red blood cells) or other blood products excluding human normal immunoglobulin (e.g. albumin, granulocytes, platelets, fresh-frozen plasma (FFP), FP24, PF-24, cryoprecipitate, protein C concentrate, cryosupernatant, or a specific non-recombinant clotting factor) at any time on the date of assessment.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient received blood products or blood product transfusion any time between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment. If 'Yes' Select the product(s) below.

Section: TREATMENTS & INTERVENTIONS: Record all interventions given between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Select all blood products that were administered.
Answer Options: 1, Platelets | 2, Cryoprecipitate | 3, Whole blood | 4, Frozen fresh plasma | 5, Fibrinogen concentrate | 6, Packed RBC (red cell concentrate)
Definition: This refers to a transfusion of blood (whole blood or packed red blood cells) or other blood products excluding human normal immunoglobulin (e.g. albumin, granulocytes, platelets, fresh-frozen plasma (FFP), FP24, PF-24, cryoprecipitate, protein C concentrate, cryosupernatant, or a specific non-recombinant clotting factor) at any time on the date of assessment. Platelets refers to the transfer of blood platelets from a donor to a recipient or reinfusion to the donor. Cryoprecipitate refers to a frozen blood product prepared from frozen plasma that contains fibrinogen (factor I), antihemophilic factor (factor VIII), factor XIII, von Willebrand factor (vWF) and fibronectin. Whole blood refers to intravenous administration of whole blood (blood that contains plasma and red blood cells) into an individual. Packed RBC refers to red blood cells from a unit of whole blood following removal of most of the plasma, leaving a unit with a haematocrit of about 60%. Fresh frozen plasma refers to the plasma that is separated from the whole blood and frozen quickly after a blood donation in order to be used for blood transfusions. Fibrinogen concentrate is a haemostatic agent used for the treatment of acute bleeding episodes in patients with congenital fibrinogen deficiency, including afibrinogenemia and hypofibrinogenemia.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option(s) corresponding to the blood product(s) that were administered.

Section: TREATMENTS & INTERVENTIONS: Record all interventions given between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Completion Guideline: Record the number of units the patient received between 00:00 and 24:00 on day of assessment in millilitres (mL).

Completion Guideline: Record the number of units the patient received between 00:00 and 24:00 on day of assessment in millilitres (mL).

Question: Intravenous immunoglobulin
Definition: This refers to immunoglobulin preparations, containing primarily Immunoglobulin G (IgG), that are used as intravenous infusions. Examples include Octagam®, Intragam P®, KIOVIG®, Flebogamma 5% DIF®, Carimune NF®, Gamunex®, Gammagard S/D®, Gammagard Liquid®, Gammaked® and Privigen®.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient received intravenous immunoglobulin between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on the day of assessment.

Question: Plasmapheresis / plasma exchange
Definition: Plasmapheresis (plasma exchange) refers to the extracorporeal separation of blood components, resulting in a filtered product. Methods include discontinuous flow centrifugation, continuous flow centrifugation and plasma filtration.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient received plasmapheresis between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on the day of assessment.

Section: TREATMENTS & INTERVENTIONS: Record all interventions given between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Antibiotics
Definition: Antibiotic refers to any agent(s) that selectively target bacteria. Topical preparations should not be recorded.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient received antibiotics between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment

Section: TREATMENTS & INTERVENTIONS: Record all interventions given between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Corticosteroids
Definition: Corticosteroids (commonly referred to as 'steroids') refers to all types of therapeutic corticosteroid, made in the adrenal cortex (the outer part of the adrenal gland). They are also made in the laboratory. Examples include: prednisolone, prednisone, methyl-prednisolone, dexamethasone, hydrocortisone, fluticasone, betametasone. Topical preparations are not included, but inhaled preparations are included.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient received 'steroids' between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment.

Section: TREATMENTS & INTERVENTIONS: Record all interventions given between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Other intervention(s) or procedure(s)
Definition: This refers to any other specific therapeutic intervention(s) or procedure(s) not otherwise characterised that you believe may be relevant.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if other intervention(s) or procedure(s) were used between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment.

Section: TREATMENTS & INTERVENTIONS: Record all interventions given between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Please specify other intervention(s) or procedure(s)
Definition: This refers to any other specific therapeutic intervention(s) or procedure(s) not otherwise characterised that you believe may be relevant.

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Supplemental oxygen
Definition: This refers to any method of oxygen therapy that may be delivered via nose cannula, mask or non-invasive or invasive ventilation.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient received supplemental oxygen between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment.

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Nasal prongs
Definition: This refers to nasal prongs or nasal cannluae which deliver oxygen through two small prongs or cannulae insterted into the nostrils.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this mode of respiratory support was used to deliver supplemental oxygen to the patient between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment.

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Face mask
Definition: This refers to a simple oxygen face mask which is a device placed over a patient's nose, mouth, or tracheostomy to administer oxygen to the airway.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this mode of respiratory support was used to deliver supplemental oxygen to the patient between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment.

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: High flow nasal oxygen
Definition: This refers to high -flow nasal oxygen therapy which is a non-invasive respiratory support that delivers warmed, humidified, oxygen-enriched air to patients at flow rates greater than those typically delivered by standard-flow oxygen devices.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this mode of respiratory support was used to deliver supplemental oxygen to the patient between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment.
Metathesaurus: C4761117, High-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Non-invasive ventilation
Definition: This refers to non-invasive ventilation which provides ventilatory support through the patient's upper airway using a mask or similar device, without the need for tracheal intubation. Examples include Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) and Biphasic Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (BiPAP).
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this mode of respiratory support was used to deliver supplemental oxygen to the patient between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment.

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Type of non-invasive ventilation
Definition: This refers to the type of non-invasive respiratory support or ventilation (NIV) used. Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) is a technique which uses a continuously maintains airway pressure above atmospheric pressure throughout the respiratory cycle to support spontaneous breathing activity. Biphasic Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (BPAP) uses a time-cycled change of the applied positive airway pressure level to support spontaneous breathing activity.
Completion Guideline: Select the single most appropriate option corresponding to the type of NIV used between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment.
Metathesaurus: C0199451, Continuous Positive Airway Pressure | C0419004, Dual pressure spontaneous ventilation support'

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Specify other type of non-invasive ventilation
Definition: This refers to the type of non-invasive respiratory support or ventilation (NIV) used.
Completion Guideline: If 'Other', specify other type of non-invasive ventilation.

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Invasive ventilation
Definition: Thsi refers to invasive mechanical ventilation (IMV) which indicates that patient has undergone tracheal intubation, to mechanically assist or replace spontaneous breathing in patients by use of a powered device that forces oxygenated air into the lungs. The mode of intubation may be orotracheal, nasotracheal, or via a cricothyrotomy or tracheotomy.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this mode of respiratory support was used to deliver supplemental oxygen to the patient between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment.

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: ECLS / ECMO
Definition: This refers to Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation (ECMO) also called to as Extracorporeal life support (ECLS) which is application of a life support system that circulates the blood through an oxygenating system, and may consist of a pump, a membrane oxygenator, and a heat exchanger.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this mode of respiratory support was used to deliver supplemental oxygen to the patient between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment.

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Type of ECLS / ECMO
Definition: This refers to the type of Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation (ECMO), also called Extracorporeal life support (ECLS). Veno-venous (venous-venous) ECMO / ECLS is used to support the lungs and veno-arterial (venous-arterial) ECLS / ECMO is used to support the lungs and heart.
Completion Guideline: Select the single most appropriate option corresponding to the type of ECLS / ECMO used between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment.
Metathesaurus: C5192099, Venovenous ECMO | C5192097, Venoarterial ECMO

Question: Prone positioning
Definition: This refers to prone positioning which is the act of having the patient lying in the prone position to assist ventilation. It includes both invasive ventilation (intubated) patients and non-intubated or self-ventilating patients.

Question: ICU / ITU / HDU / Intermediate Care Unit admission

Question: Neuromuscular blocking agents
Definition: This refers to the use of neuromuscular blockers between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment.. Examples include Atracurium, Cisatracurium, Nimbex, Norcuron, Pancuronium, Pavulon, Rocuronium, Tracrium, Vecuronium, Zemuron.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if neuromuscular blockers were used between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment.

Section: ADVANCED CARE INTERVENTIONS: Record all advanced care interventions given between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Inhaled nitric oxide
Definition: This refers to nitric oxide as in inhalant between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment. Inhaled nitric oxide is typically used for hypoxic respiratory failure, among other uses.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if inhaled nitric oxide was used any time between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment.
Metathesaurus: C1135443, Administration of inhaled nitric oxide

Section: ADVANCED CARE INTERVENTIONS: Record all advanced care interventions given between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Tracheostomy inserted

Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if a tracheostomy was inserted at any time between 00:00 and 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: ADVANCED CARE INTERVENTIONS: Record all advanced care interventions given between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Renal replacement therapy (RRT) or dialysis / hemofiltration
Definition: This refers to treatments that substitute for the blood-filtering function of the kidneys. It includes dialysis (hemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis), hemofiltration, and hemodiafiltration. It may be intermittent or continuous.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if renal replacement therapy was done any time between 00:00 and 24:00 on day of assessment.
Metathesaurus: C3649547, Continuous Renal Replacement Therapy | C5197699, Prolonged Intermittent Renal Replacement Therapy

Section: ADVANCED CARE INTERVENTIONS: Record all advanced care interventions given between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Type of renal replacement therapy (RRT) or dialysis / hemofiltration
Definition: This refers to treatments that substitute for the blood-filtering function of the kidneys. It includes dialysis (hemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis), hemofiltration, and hemodiafiltration. It may be intermittent or continuous. Intermittent refers to procedures with non-continuous blood purification (e.g., dialysis, filtration and/or perfusion) via vascular access by increasing blood flow rate. Continuous refers to procedures with continuous blood purification (e.g., dialysis, filtration or perfusion) via vascular access designed to mimic kidney function in kidney diseases.
Completion Guideline: Select the single most appropriate option corresponding to the type of renal replacement therapy (RRT) or dialysis / hemofiltration
Metathesaurus: C3649547, Continuous Renal Replacement Therapy | C5197699, Prolonged Intermittent Renal Replacement Therapy

Section: ADVANCED CARE INTERVENTIONS: Record all advanced care interventions given between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Any vasopressor / inotropic support
Definition: This refers to continuous use of a vasopressor or inotrope for at least one hour. A vasopressor is a pharmaceutical agent that causes vasoconstriction. Agents include norepinephrine, epinephrine, vasopressin, terlipressin and phenylephrine. An inotrope is a pharmaceutical agent that alters the force of myocardial contractility. Commonly used 'positive' inotropes include dobutamine, dopamine, milrinone and adrenaline (epinephrine).
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this agent was used for at least one hour between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment. Indicate the amount used below.
Metathesaurus: C5396785, Vasopressor therapy | C5880944, Inotropic therapy

Section: LABORATORY RESULTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Enter Laboratory Results data for this date?
Definition: This section refers only to those laboratory tests that were performed at the time that the patient stayed in the clinical facility (hospital) and collected on the date of assessment. In general, results that were rejected by the clinical team (e.g. haemolysed blood samples, contaminated microbiology results) should not be reported.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if laboratory samples were taken on the date of assessment. If no laboratory samples were taken on the date of assessment indicate 'No' and skip to the next section. In general, do not report results that have been rejected by the clinical team (e.g. haemolysed sample). Unless otherwise specified, if there are multiple measurements, please report the measure furthest from the normal physiological or laboratory range between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment.

Section: LABORATORY RESULTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time Ratio / APTR
Definition: This refers to the activated partial thromboplastin ratio which is calculated by dividing the patient's aPTT result by the mean normal aPTT value for the laboratory. . The result is a ratio and therefore has no units.
Completion Guideline: Write the APTR.

Section: LABORATORY RESULTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: International Normalized Ratio / INR
Definition: Serum INR (international normalised ratio) is a ratio used to standardize prothrombin time (PT) results and is derived from the ratio of a patient's PT to a control PT, adjusted for the sensitivity of the thromboplastin reagent. The result is a ratio and therefore has no units.

Question: D-Dimer (mg/L)
Definition: D-Dimer is a measure for the concentration of fibrin degradation products (FDPs) in a sample. FDPs are protein fragments produced by the enzymatic action of plasmin on fibrinogen and fibrin) and are an aid in detecting the presence and degree of intravascular coagulation and fibrinolysis (the dissolution of the fibrin in a blood clot) and in monitoring therapy for disseminated intravascular coagulation (nonlocalized clotting in the blood vessels).
Completion Guideline: Write the serum D-dimer (mg/L)

Section: IMAGING
Question: Enter Imaging data for this date?
Definition: This refers only to those imaging or radiological test(s) that were performed at the time that the patient stayed in the clinical facility (hospital) and collected on the date of assessment.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if imaging or radiological test(s) were performed at the time that the patient stayed in the clinical facility (hospital) and collected on the date of assessment.

Section: IMAGING
Question: Chest X-ray performed
Definition: This refers to any chest x-ray that was performed at the time the patient stayed in the clinical facility (hospital) and collected on the date of assessment. Chest x-ray refers to radiological visualization of the chest and organs of the thoracic cavity; not restricted to visualization of the lungs, using x-rays.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if any chest x-ray was performed at the time the patient stayed in the clinical facility (hospital) and collected on the date of assessment.

Section: IMAGING
Question: Chest X-ray date
Definition: This refers to the date when the chest x-ray was performed.
Completion Guideline: Write the date in which the chest x-ray was performed (use the format DD/MM/YYYY).

Section: IMAGING
Question: Chest X-ray findings associated with this illness.
Answer Options: 1, Normal or no acute change | 5, Abnormal or acute change | 99, Unknown
Definition: This refers to chest X-ray findings associated with this illness.
Completion Guideline: Select the single most appropriate option corresponding to the chest X-ray findings associated with this illness.
Metathesaurus: C0239026, Standard chest X-ray normal | C0436503, Standard chest X-ray abnormal

Section: IMAGING
Question: New infiltrates present on X-ray
Answer Options: 1, Yes, bilateral | 2, Yes, unilateral | 0, No | 99, Unknown
Definition: This refers to new pulmonary infiltrates present on the current chest x-ray, not visualised on previous chest radiographs of the patient. Pulmonary infiltrates result when a substance denser than air (e.g., pus, oedema, blood, surfactant, protein, or cells) is present within the lung parenchyma. Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates are present in both lungs. Unilateral pulmonary infiltrates are present in one lung only.
Completion Guideline: Select the single most appropriate option corresponding to the new pulmonary infiltrates present on the current chest x-ray, not visualised on previous chest radiographs of the patient.

Section: IMAGING
Question: Infiltrates on X-ray consistent with
Answer Options: 1, Viral pneumonitis | 2, Bacterial pneumonia |3, Pulmonary oedema| 99, Unknown
Definition: This refers to the pathological condition with which the pulmonary infiltrates on chest x-ray may be consistent with. Viral pneumonitis characteristically produces bilateral perihilar peribronchial thickening and interstitial infiltrates which, particularly in children, due to their small-calibre airways, can result in areas of atelectasis or air trapping. Bacterial pneumonia characteristically produces focal segmental (i.e. bronchopneumonia) or lobar pulmonary opacities (i.e. lobar pneumonia). Pulmonary oedema may be characterised by cephalisation of upper lobe vessels, interstitial opacities, peribronchovascular cuffing, septal lines (Kerley B lines), airspace opacification (filling of the alveoli with fluid) which can have a perihilar or 'batwing' distribution when severe and acute; and pleural effusion.
Completion Guideline: Select all that apply.
Metathesaurus: C0032310, Pneumonia, Viral | C0004626, Pneumonia, Bacterial | C0034063, Pulmonary Oedema

Section: IMAGING
Question: Pleural effusion on X-ray
Definition: This refers to presence of fluid in the pleural cavity resulting from excessive transudation or exudation from the pleural surfaces.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if pleural effusion was visualised on chest x-ray.

Section: IMAGING
Question: Pleural effusion on X-ray details
Definition: This refers to the location of the pleural effusion.
Completion Guideline: Indicate the location of the pleural effusion.

Section: IMAGING
Question: Side(s) where pleural effusion identified
Definition: This refers to the side where the unilateral pleural effusion is located.
Completion Guideline: Indicate the side of the pleural effusion.

Section: IMAGING
Question: CT chest performed
Definition: This refers to computed tomography imaging of the chest.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if any CT chest was performed at the time the patient stayed in the clinical facility (hospital) and collected on the date of assessment.

Section: IMAGING
Question: CT chest findings associated with this illness
Answer Options: 1, Normal or no acute change | 5, Abnormal or acute change | 99, Unknown
Definition: Refers to the findings identified on the CT chest. Pulmonary infiltrates refers to the presence of pulmonary or lung infiltrates and can include alveolar, air space, interstitial, or nodular infiltrates and typically refers to a substance or type of cell that is foreign to the lung, or accumulates in greater than normal quantity within it.
Completion Guideline: Select the single most appropriate option corresponding to the chest CT findings associated with this illness.

Section: IMAGING
Question: New infiltrates present on CT
Answer Options: 1, Yes, bilateral | 2, Yes, unilateral | 0, No | 99, Unknown
Definition: This refers to new pulmonary infiltrates present on the current chest CT scan, not visualised on previous chest radiographs of the patient. Pulmonary infiltrates result when a substance denser than air (e.g., pus, oedema, blood, surfactant, protein, or cells) is present within the lung parenchyma. Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates are present in both lungs. Unilateral pulmonary infiltrates are present in one lung only.
Completion Guideline: Select the single most appropriate option corresponding to the new pulmonary infiltrates present on the current chest CT scan, not visualised on previous chest radiographs of the patient.

Section: IMAGING
Question: Infiltrates on CT chest consistent with
Answer Options: 1, Viral pneumonitis | 2, Bacterial pneumonia |3, Pulmonary oedema| 99, Unknown
Definition: This refers to the pathological condition with which the pulmonary infiltrates on chest x-ray may be consistent with. Viral pneumonitis characteristically produces bilateral perihilar peribronchial thickening and interstitial infiltrates which, particularly in children, due to their small-calibre airways, can result in areas of atelectasis or air trapping. Bacterial pneumonia characteristically produces focal segmental (i.e. bronchopneumonia) or lobar pulmonary opacities (i.e. lobar pneumonia). Pulmonary oedema may be characterised by cephalisation of upper lobe vessels, interstitial opacities, peribronchovascular cuffing, septal lines (Kerley B lines), airspace opacification (filling of the alveoli with fluid) which can have a perihilar or 'batwing' distribution when severe and acute; and pleural effusion.
Completion Guideline: Select all that apply.
Metathesaurus: C0032310, Pneumonia, Viral | C0004626, Pneumonia, Bacterial | C0034063, Pulmonary Oedema

Question: Ascites
Definition: Ascites refers to a pathological increase of fluid in the peritoneal cavity.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' If ascites were identified on ultrasound on date of assessment. Indicate 'No' if there was no ascites on ultrasound on date of assessment. If the peritoneal cavity was not examined by ultrasound for ascites on date of assessment indicate 'Unknown'.

Section: IMAGING
Question: Ascites grading
Definition: Mild/small ascites (grade 1) is detectable only by ultrasonography and typically requires approximately 100mL of fluid (where normal volume is approximately 25-50mL); Moderate ascites (grade 2) implying at least 500-1000mL of peritoneal fluid and detected with physical examination; Severe ascites (grade 3) refers to the manifestation of grossly distended abdomen, may be described as tense ascites.
Completion Guideline: Select the single most appropriate option corresponding to the grade of ascites detected on ultrasound imaging.

Indicate 'Unknown' if the pleural space was not examined by ultrasound for pleural effusion(s) on date of assessment.

Topical preparations are not included, but inhaled preparations are included.

Section: PATHOGEN TESTING: Results of all types of sample and pathogen testing
Question: Biospecimen type
Definition: This refers to the type of a clinical specimen collected for pathogen testing. Nasal / Nasopharyngeal (NP) swab refers to collection biological material from within the nasal passages/nasopharynx. Throat swab refers to collection biological material from within the throat/oropharynx. Combined nasal/NP + throat swab refers to collection using both nasal / nasopharyngeal (NP) swab and throat swab. Sputum refers to material coughed up from the lungs and expectorated via the mouth. Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL) refers to washing out of the lungs with saline or mucolytic agents for diagnostic or therapeutic purposes. Endotracheal aspirate (ETA) refers to collection of specimen from endotracheal tube. Eye swab refers to collection of biological sample from the surface of the eye. Lesion swab refers to collection of biological sample from a lesion on the skin or mucous membrane. Semen refers to the secretion of male reproductive organs discharged upon ejaculation. Faeces / rectal swab refers to biological sample collected from faecal matter or from the rectum by swabbing.
Completion Guideline: Select the single most appropriate option that represents the type of clinical specimen collected for pathogen testing.

Question: Stroke / cerebrovascular accident
Definition: Defined as a sudden loss of neurological function secondary to haemorrhage or ischemia in the brain parenchyma due to a vascular event. Stroke may be a clinical diagnosis, with or without supportive radiological findings.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Section: COMPLICATIONS: Experienced at any time from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Severe neurological disease
Definition: This refers to various neurological manifestations including meningitis, encephalitis, encephalopathy, acute symptomatic seizures, intracranial haemorrhage or stroke, and Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS). Meningitis is an inflammatory disease of the leptomeninges, the tissues surrounding the brain and spinal cord, and is defined by an abnormal number of white blood cells in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) within an appropriate clinical context and with or without supportive radiological findings. Encephalitis refers to inflammation of the brain. In comparison with meningitis, in encephalitis, abnormalities in brain function are expected, including altered mental status, motor or sensory deficits, altered behaviour and personality changes, and speech or movement disorders. It is defined by an altered mental status lasting ?24 hours along with two of the following criteria: documented fever >/= 38°C (100.4°F); white blood cell count (WBC) in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) >/= 5  cells/mm^3; generalized or partial seizures not fully attributable to a preexisting seizure disorder; new onset of focal neurological findings; presence of compatible acute lesion on neuroimaging; abnormality on electroencephalography that is consistent with encephalitis and not attributable to another cause. As outlined by the 2013 International Encephalitis Consortium. Seizures are defined as an intermittent abnormality of nervous system physiology characterised by a transient occurrence of sudden, violent, irregular movement of the body, caused by involuntary contraction of muscles due to abnormal excessive or synchronous neuronal activity in the brain. An established history of epilepsy is not required. Stroke refers to a sudden loss of neurological function secondary to haemorrhage or ischemia in the brain parenchyma due to a vascular event. Stroke may be a clinical diagnosis, with or without supportive radiological findings. Intracranial haemorrhage refers to haemorrhage/bleeding occurring within the skull. Intracranial haemorrhage encompasses four broad types of haemorrhage: epidural haemorrhage, subdural haemorrhage, subarachnoid haemorrhage, and intraparenchymal haemorrhage. Guillain-Barre syndrome refers to a rapidly progressive autoimmune disorder of the peripheral nervous system characterized by limb paraesthesia, areflexia, and generalized muscle weakness or paralysis that often begins in the legs and spreads to the arms, torso, and face. Required features include progressive weakness of the arms and/or legs, ranging from minimal weakness of the legs to total paralysis of all four limbs, and including the trunk, bulbar and facial muscles, and external ophthalmoplegia; and areflexia or decreased deep tendon reflexes in weak limbs. Supportive features include symptom progression over days to four weeks; Relatively symmetric, bilateral symptoms; Pain in the trunk or limbs; Cranial nerve symptoms or signs; Autonomic dysfunction; Sensory dysfunction that is mild; No fever at symptom onset; CSF with elevated protein and normal to mildly elevated leukocyte count (usually <5 cells/mm3); Electrodiagnostic abnormalities consistent with GBS; Recovery starting two to four weeks after progression halts.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Question: Encephalitis
Definition: Encephalitis refers to inflammation of the brain. It is defined by an altered mental status lasting greater or equal to 24 hours along with two of the following criteria: documented fever greater or equal to 38° C (100.4°F); white blood cell count (WBC) in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) greater or equal to 5/mm³; generalized or partial seizures not fully attributable to a preexisting seizure disorder; new onset of focal neurological findings; presence of compatible acute lesion on neuroimaging; abnormality on electroencephalography that is consistent with encephalitis and not attributable to another cause. As outlined by the 2013 International Encephalitis Consortium.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Question: Cardiac ischaemia
Definition: Defined as diminished blood and oxygen supply to the heart muscle as indicated by typical symptomatology (e.g. chest pain) and confirmed by an electrocardiogram (showing ischaemic changes, e.g. ST depression or elevation) and/or cardiac enzyme elevation (e.g. raised troponin I).

Question: Endocarditis
Definition: This refers to an inflammation of the endocardium (inner lining of the heart). It is often caused by a primary disorder or microorganisms including bacteria, viruses, fungi, and rickettsiae Diagnosis of infective endocarditis is according to modified Duke criteria, using evidence from microbiological results, echocardiogram and clinical signs.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Question: Cardiomyopathy

Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Question: Congestive heart failure
Definition: Defined as failure of the heart to pump a sufficient amount of blood to meet the needs of the body tissues, resulting in tissue congestion and oedema. Signs and symptoms include shortness of breath, pitting oedema, enlarged tender liver, engorged neck veins, and pulmonary rales. There are many ways to assess cardiac function (e.g. echocardiography, right heart catheterization, functional testing and supportive biochemical tests). However, there is no diagnostic test for heart failure, since it is largely a clinical diagnosis that is based upon a careful history and physical examination.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Section: COMPLICATIONS: Experienced at any time from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.

Question: Viral pneumonia / pneumonitis
Definition: Defined as pneumonitis (pneumonia) that is believed to occur as a direct consequence of an infecting virus/infecting viruses. Viral pneumonitis may be a clinical diagnosis, with or without radiographic or histopathological evidence of lung consolidation. Although preferred, identification of the infecting viral species is not essential to make the diagnosis.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Section: COMPLICATIONS: Experienced at any time from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Bacterial pneumonia
Definition: Defined as pneumonia (pneumonitis) that is believed to occur as a direct consequence of infecting bacteria. It is an acute infection of the lung parenchyma caused by bacteria (e.g., Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, Chlamydia pneumoniae, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, and Legionella pneumophila). Signs and symptoms include productive cough, fever, chills, shortness of breath, and chest pain. Bacterial pneumonia may be a clinical diagnosis, with or without radiographic or histopathological evidence of lung consolidation. Although preferred, identification of the infecting bacterial species is not essential to make the diagnosis.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Question: Fungal pneumonia
Definition: This refers to an infectious of the lungs caused by one or more endemic or opportunistic fungi. Examples of endemic fungi include Histoplasma capsulatum, Coccidioides immitis, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Sporothrix schenckii, Cryptococcus neoformans and opportunistic fungi include Candida species, Aspergillus species, Mucor species.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Question: Pneumothorax
Definition: Defined as the abnormal presence of air in the pleural cavity (between the lungs and the chest wall), causing collapse of the lung. It may be diagnosed clinically, usually with radiological confirmation.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Section: COMPLICATIONS: Experienced at any time from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Pleural effusion
Definition: Defined as increased amounts of fluid within the pleural cavity. Symptoms include shortness of breath, cough, and chest pain. It is usually caused by lung infections, congestive heart failure, pleural and lung tumours, connective tissue disorders, and trauma. It may be diagnosed clinically, with or without radiological or interventional confirmation.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Section: COMPLICATIONS: Experienced at any time from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Cryptogenic organising pneumonia (COP)
Definition: This refers to an idiopathic diffuse interstitial lung disease, diagnosed radiologically (multiple consolidative or ground glass opacities) or histologically (granulation tissue and chronic inflammatory infiltrate in alveoli). Formerly known as bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP).
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Section: COMPLICATIONS: Experienced at any time from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Bronchiolitis
Definition: This refers to Inflammation of the bronchioles. In adults, bronchiolitis is a general term used to describe a nonspecific Inflammation of the bronchioles characterized by swelling of the bronchioles and mucus accumulation. It is usually caused by the respiratory syncytial virus and affects children. Signs and symptoms include coughing, wheezing, and shortness of breath. In the majority of cases, open or thoracoscopic lung biopsy is required to make a definitive diagnosis, although tissue confirmation may not be necessary in patients with a clear predisposition and typical radiological findings. In infants and children, bronchiolitis is defined as an illness in children <2 years of age, characterized by wheezing and airway obstruction due to primary infection or reinfection with a viral or bacterial pathogen, resulting in inflammation of the small airways/bronchioles. This is a clinical diagnosis, generally in children < 2 years old.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Section: COMPLICATIONS: Experienced at any time from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS)
Definition: Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a non-cardiogenic pulmonary oedema and diffuse lung inflammation syndrome that often complicates critical illness. Diagnosis of ARDS is based on fulfilling three criteria: a) Acute onset (within 1 week) b) Bilateral opacities on chest radiography or computed tomography (CT), or bilateral B lines and/or consolidations on ultrasound not fully explained by effusions, atelectasis, or nodules/masses. c)PaO2/FiO2 (arterial to inspired oxygen) ratio of ?300 or SpO2/FiO2 (pulse oximetric saturation to inspired oxygen) ratio of ?315.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Section: COMPLICATIONS: Experienced at any time from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.

Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.
