Question: Ascites
Definition: This refers to pathological increase in amount of fluid in the abdominal cavity (ascites). It may be diagnosed clinically, with or without radiological or interventional confirmation. Symptoms associated with ascites include increasing abdominal girth, abdominal discomfort and distension, shortness of breath.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Question: Pancreatitis
Definition: This refers to acute inflammation of the pancreas. Acute pancreatitis is diagnosed clinically with supporting biochemical (e.g serum amylase or serum lipase) and/or radiological and/or histological evidence. All evidence should be considered together, since no single feature is diagnostic of acute pancreatitis.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Section: COMPLICATIONS: Experienced at any time from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Acute hepatitis
Definition: This refers to acute hepatic injury from inflammation resulting in fever, abdominal pain, jaundice accompanied with increased liver function tests (serum alanine transaminase (ALT) and / or aspartate transaminase (AST) activity). Etiologies include viral hepatitis, drugs, toxins, and autoimmune disorders.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Section: COMPLICATIONS: Experienced at any time from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Severe liver disease (new onset)
Definition: Defined as new onset cirrhosis and portal hypertension with variceal bleeding, ascites, jaundice or status post liver transplantation.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Section: COMPLICATIONS: Experienced at any time from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Hepatic encephalopathy (any grade)
Definition: This refers to a neuropsychiatric syndrome caused by advanced liver insufficiency and/or portosystemic shunt without evidence of other primary neurological disease. Clinical features include lethargy; confusion (can progress to coma); asterixis; pathologic nystagmus; brisk oculovestibular reflexes; decorticate and decerebrate posturing; muscle spasticity; and bilateral extensor plantar reflexes.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Section: COMPLICATIONS: Experienced at any time from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Jaundice
Definition: This refers to a clinical manifestation of hyperbilirubinemia, characterized by the yellowish staining of the skin, mucous membrane and/or sclera.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Section: COMPLICATIONS: Experienced at any time from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Liver dysfunction
Definition: This refers to a finding that indicates abnormal liver function, may refer to any of the following: Jaundice; Hyperbilirubinemia (blood bilirubin level twice the upper limit of the normal range); An increase in alanine transaminase (ALT) or aspartate transaminase (AST) that is twice the upper limit of the normal range.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Question: Haematological complications
Definition: Defined as any complications of the haematological system
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Section: COMPLICATIONS: Experienced at any time from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Thromboembolism
Definition: Defined as the occlusion of the lumen of a blood vessel by a thrombus that has migrated from a distal site via the blood stream.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Section: COMPLICATIONS: Experienced at any time from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Pulmonary embolism (PE)
Definition: Defined as the occlusion of a pulmonary artery by thrombus, air or fat. Physician diagnosis based on clinical signs and/or radiological tests (e.g. computed tomographic pulmonary angiography and/or ventilation/perfusion scanning).
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Section: COMPLICATIONS: Experienced at any time from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
Definition: Defined as the presence of a blood clot in a deep vein, predominantly in the lower extremity, but may include the pelvis or upper extremity. Symptoms may include pain, swelling, warmth, and redness in the affected area. Physician diagnosis based on clinical signs and/or appropriate diagnostic imaging e.g. ultrasonography.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Section: COMPLICATIONS: Experienced at any time from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Other thromboembolism (not PE or DVT)
Definition: This refers to thromboembolic diagnoses not specified above.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Question: Severe bleeding (requiring intervention)
Definition: Defined as bleeding resulting in haemodynamic compromise necessitating intervention, namely transfusion. This includes World Health Organisation (WHO) Bleeding Scale grade 3 or 4.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Definition: This refers to the location of bleeding/haemorrhage site(s). Petechiae refer to small reddish or purplish spots in skin or mucous membrane as a result of localised haemorrhage. Nose bleeding refers to haemorrhage localized in the nose. Gum bleeding refers to haemorrhage affecting the gingiva. Gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding refers to haemorrhage in any segment of the gastrointestinal tract from oesophagus to rectum. Urinary tract bleeding refers to haemorrhage originating from any part of the urinary system. Vaginal bleeding refers to haemorrhage originating from vagina, unrelated to normal menstruation.

Section: COMPLICATIONS: Experienced at any time from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Anaemia
Definition: Defined as a reduction in the number of red blood cells, the amount of haemoglobin, and/or the volume of packed red blood cells. Signs and symptoms of anaemia may include pallor of the skin and mucous membranes, shortness of breath, palpitations of the heart, soft systolic murmurs, lethargy, and fatigability. The World Health Organization thresholds are used for defining anaemia, in adult males aged over 15 years anaemia is defined by a haemoglobin <130g/L (<8.1mmol/L); for non-pregnant females aged over 15 years thresholds are <120g/L (<7.4mmol/L), for children aged under 5 years and pregnant women as a haemoglobin <110 g/L (6.8 mmol/L)
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Section: COMPLICATIONS: Experienced at any time from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Coagulation disorder / DIC
Definition: Coagulopathy (bleeding disorder) is defined as a condition in which there is a deviation from or interruption of the normal coagulation properties of the blood (normal blood clotting is disrupted). Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is a specific type of coagulopathy which blood starts to coagulate throughout the whole body. Acute DIC is confirmed by demonstrating increased thrombin generation (e.g. decreased fibrinogen) and increased fibrinolysis (e.g. elevated fibrin degradation products and D-dimer). The diagnosis of chronic DIC may be largely based upon evidence of microangiopathy on the blood film and increased levels of fibrin degradation products and particularly D-dimer.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Section: COMPLICATIONS: Experienced at any time from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Renal/genitourinary complications
Definition: Defined as any complications of the renal/genitourinary system
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Section: COMPLICATIONS: Experienced at any time from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Acute renal injury / acute renal failure
Definition: Acute kidney injury is defined when one of the following criteria is met: Serum creatinine rises by >= 26umol/L or 0.3mg/dL within 48 hours; or serum creatinine rises >= 1.5 fold from the reference value, which is known or presumed to have occurred within the prior 7 days; or urine output is <0.5ml/kg/hr for >6 consecutive hours.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Section: COMPLICATIONS: Experienced at any time from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Urinary tract infection
Definition: This refers to inflammatory responses of the epithelium of the urinary tract to microbial invasions. They are often bacterial infections with associated bacteruria and pyuria.

Section: COMPLICATIONS: Experienced at any time from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Rhabdomyolysis
Definition: Rhabdomyolysis is a syndrome characterised by muscle necrosis and the release of myoglobin into the blood, resulting from muscle injury. Diagnosis is made in a patient with either an acute neuromuscular illness or dark urine without other symptoms, plus a marked acute elevation in creatine kinase. The creatine kinase is typically at least five times the upper limit of normal (there is no diagnostic threshold to establish the diagnosis, however). Muscle biopsy, electromyography, radiological imaging and the presence of myoglobinuria are not required for the diagnosis.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Section: COMPLICATIONS: Experienced at any time from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Myositis
Definition: Myositis is defined as an inflammatory process affecting the skeletal muscles. Causes include infections, injuries, and autoimmune disorders. It may be a clinical diagnosis with supporting evidence from laboratory tests e.g. elevated serum creatine kinase; histological confirmation is not required to make the diagnosis. Myositis can occur without subsequent progression to rhabdomyolysis.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Section: COMPLICATIONS: Experienced at any time from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.

Question: Cellulitis
Definition: Defined as an acute, diffuse, and suppurative inflammation of loose connective tissue, particularly the deep subcutaneous tissues, and sometimes muscle, which is most commonly seen as a result of infection. Diagnosis is made on clinical signs and symptoms, it can be supported by microbiological evidence.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Question: Bacteraemia
Definition: Defined as the presence of bacteria in blood, most often detected through blood culture investigation. Episodes of suspected artefactual contamination of a blood culture should not be recorded.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if bacteraemia occurred at any time during hospitalisation. Indicate 'No', if bacteraemia never occurred or if only bacteria grown were believed to be skin contaminants (e.g. coagulase negative Staphylococci or diphtheroids).

Section: COMPLICATIONS: Experienced at any time from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Hyperglycemia
Definition: For adults, is defined as an abnormally high level of glucose in the blood, blood glucose level that is consistently above 126mg/dL or 7 mmol/L. For children, is defined as a blood glucose level consistently above 8.3 mmol/L.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if bacteraemia occurred at any time during hospitalisation. Indicate 'No', if bacteraemia never occurred or if only bacteria grown were believed to be skin contaminants (e.g. coagulase negative Staphylococci or diphtheroids).

Section: COMPLICATIONS: Experienced at any time from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Hypoglycaemia
Definition: This refers to abnormally low level of glucose in the blood. For adults, is defined as an abnormally low level of glucose in the blood, a blood glucose level that is consistently below 70mg/dL or 4 mmol/L. For children, is defined as a blood glucose level below 3 mmol/L.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Section: COMPLICATIONS: Experienced at any time from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Shock
Definition: Shock refers to circulatory failure, causing inadequate oxygen delivery to meet cellular metabolic needs. It is defined by the presence of any two of the following: evidence of hypoperfusion (e.g. capillary refill >2 seconds, cold clammy skin, and rapid/weak pulse, altered mental status), narrow pulse pressure (less than or equal to 20mmHg), hypotension for age, and tachycardia (>100bpm).
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Section: COMPLICATIONS: Experienced at any time from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Re-shock episodes
Definition: Re-shock or recurrent shock is defined as a separate episode of shock which occurs at least 2-6 hours after the clinical resolution of an initial episode of shock, where clinical resolution refers to a pulse pressure >25mmHg without signs of impaired perfusion. This does not include persistent shock (where no resolution is seen).
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Section: COMPLICATIONS: Experienced at any time from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Number of re-shock episodes
Definition: This refers to the number of times re-shock was identified while the patient was hospitalised.
Completion Guideline: If 'Yes', select the single most appropriate option which corresponds to the number of re-shock episodes the patient has experienced at any time during hospitalisation.

Question: Sepsis
Definition: As defined according to the 2016 SCCM/ESICM task force as a life-threatening organ dysfunction caused by a dysregulated host response to infection with the following: Organ dysfunction determined by a Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) score of greater or equal to 2 points (or quick SOFA/qSOFA score of greater or equal to 2); and a Physician-diagnosed infection (which can be supported by clinical signs and symptoms, radiologic and/or microbiologic evidence).
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during hospitalisation.

Section: INTERVENTIONS: Record interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Intravenous fluid type
Definition: This refers to the type of parenteral or intravenous (IV) fluid is prescribed as a replacement of fluid, electrolytes, calories, vitamins, and other nutritional substances. Intravenous fluids may be crystalloids (commonly including 0.9% Sodium Chloride (Normal Saline), Lactated Ringer(USP), 0.45% Sodium Chloride (Half-normal saline), 0.45% normal saline + 4% Glucose (Half-normal saline with dextrose), 0.18%-0.3% Sodium Chloride + 4% Glucose (Hypotonic saline with dextrose), 5% Glucose (Dextrose 5% in Water), Ringeracetate or Plasmalyte) or colloids (commonly including gelatins, starches or albumin).
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option corresponding to the type of intravenous or parenteral fluid(s) administered.

Section: INTERVENTIONS: Record interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Total crystalloid volume given during admission (mL)
Definition: Crystalloid fluids refer to aqueous solutions of mineral salts and other small, water-soluble molecules. They are commonly used for fluid resuscitation in the presence of hypovolemia, hemorrhage, sepsis, and dehydration Common crystalloids include 0.9% Sodium Chloride (Normal Saline), Lactated Ringer(USP), 0.45% Sodium Chloride (Half-normal saline), 0.45% normal saline + 4% Glucose (Half-normal saline with dextrose), 0.18%-0.3% Sodium Chloride + 4% Glucose (Hypotonic saline with dextrose), 5% Glucose (Dextrose 5% in Water), Ringeracetate or Plasmalyte.
Completion Guideline: Record the total volume of crystalloid fluids the patient received during admission in millilitres (mL).

Section: INTERVENTIONS: Record interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Total colloid volume given during admission (mL)
Definition: Colloid fluids are solutions that contain large molecules, such as proteins or polysaccharides, which remain in the bloodstream for a longer duration compared to crystalloids. These fluids help maintain or expand intravascular volume by drawing water into the blood vessels via oncotic pressure. Common colloids include gelatins, starches or albumin.
Completion Guideline: Record the total volume of colloid fluid the patient received during admission in millilitres (mL).

Section: INTERVENTIONS: Record interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.

Definition: This refers to the reason(s) (indication(s)) for parenteral / intravenous (IV) fluid therapy at any time during the admission. If multiple indications, select all that apply. Shock refers to circulatory failure, causing inadequate oxygen delivery to meet cellular metabolic needs. It is defined by the presence of any two of the following: evidence of hypoperfusion (e.g. capillary refill >2 seconds, cold clammy skin, and rapid/weak pulse, altered mental status), narrow pulse pressure (less than or equal to 20mmHg), hypotension for age, and tachycardia (>100bpm). High/rising haematorit refers to an elevation above the normal ratio of the volume of red blood cells to the total volume of blood. Anorexia refers to the lack or loss of appetite accompanied by an aversion to food and the inability to eat.
Completion Guideline: Select all that apply.

Section: INTERVENTIONS: Record interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Select all blood product transfusion that were administered
Answer Options: 1, Platelets | 2, Cryoprecipitate | 3, Whole blood | 4, Frozen fresh plasma | 5, Fibrinogen concentrate | 6, Packed RBC (red cell concentrate)
Definition: This refers to a transfusion of blood (whole blood or packed red blood cells) or other blood products excluding human normal immunoglobulin (e.g. albumin, granulocytes, platelets, fresh-frozen plasma (FFP), FP24, PF-24, cryoprecipitate, protein C concentrate, cryosupernatant, or a specific non-recombinant clotting factor) at any time on the date of assessment. Platelets refers to the transfer of blood platelets from a donor to a recipient or reinfusion to the donor. Cryoprecipitate refers to a frozen blood product prepared from frozen plasma that contains fibrinogen (factor I), antihemophilic factor (factor VIII), factor XIII, von Willebrand factor (vWF) and fibronectin. Whole blood refers to intravenous administration of whole blood (blood that contains plasma and red blood cells) into an individual. Packed RBC refers to red blood cells from a unit of whole blood following removal of most of the plasma, leaving a unit with a haematocrit of about 60%. Fresh frozen plasma refers to the plasma that is separated from the whole blood and frozen quickly after a blood donation in order to be used for blood transfusions. Fibrinogen concentrate is a haemostatic agent used for the treatment of acute bleeding episodes in patients with congenital fibrinogen deficiency, including afibrinogenemia and hypofibrinogenemia.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option(s) corresponding to the blood product(s) that were administered.

Question: Intravenous immunoglobulin
Definition: This refers to immunoglobulin preparations, containing primarily Immunoglobulin G (IgG), that are used as intravenous infusions. Examples include Octagam®, Intragam P®, KIOVIG®, Flebogamma 5% DIF®, Carimune NF®, Gamunex®, Gammagard S/D®, Gammagard Liquid®, Gammaked® and Privigen®.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient received intravenous immunoglobulin at any time during admission.
Standardized Term Code: 698802001, Administration of immunoglobulin by intravenous route (procedure) |

Section: INTERVENTIONS: Record interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Diuretics
Definition: This refers to class of agents that increases the production of urine by the kidney. Via various mechanism of actions, diuretics retain water in urine, thus provides a means of forced diuresis.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient received diuretic therapy at any time during admission.

Section: INTERVENTIONS: Record interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: N-acetyl cysteine
Definition: This refers to N-acetyl derivative of cysteine; used as a mucolytic agent to reduce the viscosity of mucous secretions.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient received N-acetyl cysteine (NAC) at any time during admission.

Section: INTERVENTIONS: Record interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Fluid drainage
Definition: This refers to the procedure of removing fluid from the pleural space or peritoneal cavity.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this was fluid drainage from the pleural or peritoneal cavity was performed at any time during admission.

Section: INTERVENTIONS: Record interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Reason for this drainage
Definition: This refers to the reason (indication) for fluid drainage. Ascites refers to the abnormal accumulation of fluid in the peritoneal cavity. Pleural effusion refers to presence of fluid in the pleural cavity resulting from excessive transudation or exudation from the pleural surfaces.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option corresponding to the reason (indication) for fluid drainage.

Section: INTERVENTIONS: Record interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Plasmapheresis / plasma exchange
Definition: Plasmapheresis (plasma exchange) refers to the extracorporeal separation of blood components, resulting in a filtered product. Methods include discontinuous flow centrifugation, continuous flow centrifugation and plasma filtration.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient received plasmapharesis at any time during admission.

Section: INTERVENTIONS: Record interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Days on plasma exchange support during admission
Definition: This refers to the total number of calendar days the patient was on plasma exchange support (plasmapharesis). Plasmapheresis (plasma exchange) refers to the extracorporeal separation of blood components, resulting in a filtered product. Methods include discontinuous flow centrifugation, continuous flow centrifugation and plasma filtration.
Completion Guideline: Write the total number of calendar days the patient was on plasma exchange support (plasmaphe\resis).

Section: INTERVENTIONS: Record interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Was the patient isolated at home or in hospital?
Definition: This refers to isolation of the patient at home or in hospital during this admission for pathogen of interest.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if the patient was isolation at home or in hospital during this admission for pathogen of interest.

Section: INTERVENTIONS: Record interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Date individual entered isolation
Definition: This refers to the start date of isolation of the patient at home or in hospital during this admission for pathogen of interest.
Completion Guideline: Write the date in DD/MM/YYYY format.

Question: Any surgical intervention performed in relation to the infection with pathogen of interest?
Definition: This refers to any surgical intervention that was performed in relation to the infection with pathogen of interest.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if a surgical intervention was performed in relation to the infection with pathogen of interest.

Section: INTERVENTIONS: Record interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: What was the surgery? (e.g. debridement of infected tissue)
Definition: This refers to any surgical intervention that was performed in relation to the infection with pathogen of interest.
Completion Guideline: If 'Yes', write the name of surgical intervention / procedure that was performed in relation to the infection with pathogen of interest.

Section: INTERVENTIONS: Record interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Date of first surgery
Definition: This refers to the date of the first surgical intervention that was performed in relation to the infection with pathogen of interest.
Completion Guideline: Write the date of the first surgery, use the format DD/MM/YYYY.

Section: INTERVENTIONS: Record interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Was a second surgical intervention performed in relation to the infection with pathogen of interest?
Definition: This refers to any surgical intervention that was performed in relation to the infection with pathogen of interest.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if a second surgical intervention was performed in relation to the infection with pathogen of interest.

Section: INTERVENTIONS: Record interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Date of second surgery
Definition: This refers to the date of the second surgical intervention that was performed in relation to the infection with pathogen of interest.
Completion Guideline: Write the date of the second surgery, use the format DD/MM/YYYY.

Section: INTERVENTIONS: Record interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Other intervention(s) or procedure(s)
Definition: This refers to any other specific therapeutic intervention(s) or procedure(s) administered at any time during the admission, not otherwise characterised that you believe may be relevant.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if other intervention(s) or procedure(s) were used between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment.

Section: INTERVENTIONS: Record interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Please specify other intervention(s) or procedure(s)
Definition: This refers to any other specific therapeutic intervention(s) or procedure(s) administered at any time during the admission, not otherwise characterised that you believe may be relevant.
Completion Guideline: If 'Yes', please specify the therapeutic intervention(s) or procedure(s)not otherwise characterised that you believe may be relevant.

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Any supplemental oxygen?
Definition: This refers to any method of supplemental oxygen therapy that may be delivered via nose cannula, mask or non-invasive or invasive ventilation.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced was given or prescribed supplemental oxygen therapy at any time during hospitalisation.

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Still on supplemental oxygen?
Definition: This refers to ongoing oxygen therapy that may be delivered via nose cannula, mask or non-invasive or invasive ventilation.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient is still on supplemental oxygen therapy.

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Number of calendar days the patient received any respiratory support during admission
Definition: This refers to the total number of calendar days the patient received this respiratory support during admission (includes use at any time during admission).
Completion Guideline: Write the total number of calendar days the patient received this respiratory support during admission (includes use at any time during admission).

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Maximum O2 flow volume (L/min)
Answer Options: 1, <2 L/min | 2, 2-5 L/min | 3, 6-10 L/min | 4, 11-15 L/min | 5, >15 L/min | 99, Unknown
Definition: This refers to the maximum flow volume of O2 delivered to the patient at any time during hospitalisation.
Completion Guideline: Select the maximum flow volume of O2 delivered to the patient at any time during hospitalisation.

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Nasal prongs
Definition: This refers to the mode in which the patient received supplemental oxygen on day of assessment. Nasal prongs or nasal cannluae deliver oxygen through two small prongs or cannulae insterted into the nostrils.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this mode of respiratory support was used to deliver supplemental oxygen at any time during hospitalisation

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Still ongoing?
Definition: This refers to ongoing non-invasive ventilation.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient is still on supplemental oxygen through nasal prongs.

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Number of calendar days the patient received supplemental oxygen through nasal prongs
Definition: This refers to the total number of calendar days the patient received non-invasive ventilation.
Completion Guideline: Write the total number of calendar days the patient received supplemental oxygen through nasal prongs during admission (includes use at any time during admission).

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Face mask
Definition: This refers to the mode in which the patient received supplemental oxygen on day of assessment. A simple oxygen face mask is a device placed over a patient's nose, mouth, or tracheostomy to administer oxygen to the airway.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this mode of respiratory support was used to deliver supplemental oxygen at any time during hospitalisation

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Still ongoing?
Definition: This refers to ongoing non-invasive ventilation.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient is still on supplemental oxygen through face mask.

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Number of calendar days the patient received supplemental oxygen through face mask
Definition: This refers to the total number of calendar days the patient received non-invasive ventilation.
Completion Guideline: Write the total number of calendar days the patient received supplemental oxygen through face mask during admission (includes use at any time during admission).

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: High flow nasal oxygen
Definition: This refers to the mode in which the patient received supplemental oxygen on day of assessment. High -flow nasal oxygen therapy is a non-invasive respiratory support that delivers warmed, humidified, oxygen-enriched air to patients through a high-flow nasal cannula at flow rates greater than those typically delivered by standard-flow oxygen devices.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this mode of respiratory support was used to deliver supplemental oxygen to the patient at any time during hospitalisation.
Metathesaurus: C4761117, High-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Still ongoing?
Definition: This refers to ongoing non-invasive ventilation.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient is still on high-flow nasal oxygen.

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Number of calendar days the patient received high-flow nasal oxygen
Definition: This refers to the total number of calendar days the patient received high-flow nasal oxygen.
Completion Guideline: Write the total number of calendar days the patient received high-flow nasal oxygen during admission (includes use at any time during admission).

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Non-invasive ventilation
Definition: This refers to the mode in which the patient received supplemental oxygen on day of assessment. Non-invasive ventilation refers to the provision of ventilatory support through the patient's upper airway using a mask or similar device, without the need for tracheal intubation. Examples include Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) and Biphasic Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (BiPAP).
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this mode of respiratory support was used to deliver supplemental oxygen at any time during hospitalisation

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Type of non-invasive respiratory support
Definition: Non-invasive respiratory support or ventilation (NIV) refers to the provision of ventilatory support through the patient's upper airway using a mask or similar device. It includes high-flow nasal cannula, continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and bilevel positive airway pressure (BPAP).
Completion Guideline: Select the single most appropriate option corresponding to the type of NIV used at any time during hospitalisation
Metathesaurus: C0199451, Continuous Positive Airway Pressure | C0419004, Dual pressure spontaneous ventilation support'

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Specify other type of non-invasive ventilation
Definition: Non-invasive respiratory support or ventilation (NIV) refers to the provision of ventilatory support through the patient's upper airway using a mask or similar device. It includes high-flow nasal cannula, continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and bilevel positive airway pressure (BPAP).
Completion Guideline: If 'Other', specify other type of non-invasive ventilation.

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Still ongoing?
Definition: This refers to ongoing non-invasive ventilation.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient is still on non-invasive ventilation.

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Number of calendar days the patient received non-invasive ventilation
Definition: This refers to the total number of calendar days the patient received non-invasive ventilation.
Completion Guideline: Write the total number of calendar days the patient received non-invasive ventilation during admission (includes use at any time during admission).

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Invasive ventilation
Definition: This refers to the mode in which the patient received supplemental oxygen on day of assessment. Invasive ventilation indicates that patient has undergone tracheal intubation, for the purpose of invasive mechanical ventilation. Invasive mechanical ventilation (IMV) is a method to mechanically assist or replace spontaneous breathing in patients by use of a powered device that forces oxygenated air into the lungs. The mode of intubation may be orotracheal, nasotracheal, or via a cricothyrotomy or tracheotomy.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this mode of respiratory support was used to deliver supplemental oxygen to the patient at any time during hospitalisation

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Still ongoing?
Definition: This refers to ongoing invasive ventilation.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient is still on invasive ventilation.

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Number of calendar days the patient received invasive ventilation
Definition: This refers to the total number of calendar days the patient received invasive ventilation.
Completion Guideline: Write the total number of calendar days the patient received invasive ventilation during admission (includes use at any time during admission).

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: ECLS / ECMO
Definition: This refers to the mode in which the patient received supplemental oxygen on day of assessment. Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation (ECMO) also called to as Extracorporeal life support (ECLS) refers to application of a life support system that circulates the blood through an oxygenating system, which may consist of a pump, a membrane oxygenator, and a heat exchanger.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this mode of respiratory support was used to deliver supplemental oxygen to the patient at any time during hospitalisation

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Type of ECLS / ECMO
Definition: The two main types of Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation (ECMO), also called Extracorporeal life support (ECLS), are veno-venous (venous-venous), which is used to support the lungs and veno-arterial (venous-arterial), which is used to support the lungs and heart.
Completion Guideline: Select the single most appropriate option corresponding to the type of ECLS / ECMO used at any time during hospitalisation.
Metathesaurus: C5192099, Venovenous ECMO | C5192097, Venoarterial ECMO

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Still ongoing?
Definition: This refers to ongoing ECMO/ECLS.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient is still on ECMO/ECLS.

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Number of calendar days the patient received ECLS / ECMO
Definition: This refers to the number of calendar days the patient received Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation (ECMO), also called Extracorporeal life support (ECLS).
Completion Guideline: Write the total number of calendar days the patient received ECLS/ECMO during admission (includes use at any time during admission).

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Prone positioning
Definition: Prone positioning refers to the act of having the patient lying in the prone position to assist ventilation. This includes both invasive ventilation/intubated patients and non-intubated or self-ventilating patients.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', for any patients if they have been in the prone position to aid their ventilation at any time during admission.

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: When was the prone positioning?
Answer Options: 1, During invasive ventilation | 2, Whilst self-ventilating | 99, Unknown
Definition: This refers to the type of assisted ventilation when the patient was placed in prone position. This may be either invasive ventilation / intubated patients or non-intubated / self-ventilating patients.
Completion Guideline: Specify the type of assisted ventilation administered when the patient was placed in prone position.

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Awake proning?
Definition: This refers to the practice of proning patients while awake, without sedation, to improve oxygenation.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if awake proning was used at any time during admission.

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Other respiratory support intervention(s) or procedure(s)
Definition: This refers to any other specific respiratory support intervention(s) or procedure(s) not otherwise characterised that you believe may be relevant.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if other respiratory support intervention(s) or procedure(s) were used at any time during hospitalisation

Section: RESPIRATORY SUPPORT: Record all respiratory interventions given or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Please specify other respiratory support intervention(s) or procedure(s)
Definition: This refers to any other specific respiratory support intervention(s) or procedure(s) not otherwise characterised that you believe may be relevant.
Completion Guideline: If 'Yes', please specify the respiratory support intervention(s) or procedure(s) not otherwise characterised that you believe may be relevant.

Section: ADVANCED CARE INTERVENTIONS: Record all advanced care interventions given from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Were advanced care (including acute organ support and critical care) therapeutic interventions administered during this admission?
Definition: This refers to any advanced care (including acute organ support and critical care) therapeutic intervention(s) or procedure(s) that were administered at any time during hospitalisation. This section does not include respiratory organ support interventions, which are recorded separately in another section.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if any advanced care (including acute organ support and critical care) therapeutic intervention(s) or procedure(s) were administered at any time during hospitalisation.

Definition: This refers to ongoing admission in the ICU / ITU / HDU / Intermediate Care Unit.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if the patient is stll admitted to ICU (or unit of similar level) .

Question: Date of first ICU / ITU / HDU / Intermediate Care Unit admission
Definition: This refers to the date of first admission to the ICU (or unit of similar level).
Completion Guideline: Write the date in DD/MM/YYYY format.

Definition: Refers to any admission to an intensive care unit (or unit of similar level) at any time during the patient's admission.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if the patient was admitted to ICU more than once at any time during their hospitalisation.

Section: ADVANCED CARE INTERVENTIONS: Record all advanced care interventions given from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Date of final ICU / ITU / HDU / Intermediate Care Unit admission
Definition: This refers to the date of first admission to the ICU (or unit of similar level).
Completion Guideline: Enter the date in DD/MM/YYYY format.

Section: ADVANCED CARE INTERVENTIONS: Record all advanced care interventions given from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Duration of final ICU / ITU / HDU / Intermediate Care Unit admission (days)
Definition: This refers to the total duration of final admission to the ICU (or unit of similar level).

Section: ADVANCED CARE INTERVENTIONS: Record all advanced care interventions given from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Neuromuscular blocking agents
Definition: This refers to the use of neuromuscular blockers at any time during the patient's admission. Examples include Atracurium, Cisatracurium, Nimbex, Norcuron, Pancuronium, Pavulon, Rocuronium, Tracrium, Vecuronium, Zemuron.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if neuromuscular blockers were used any time during this admission.

Section: ADVANCED CARE INTERVENTIONS: Record all advanced care interventions given from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Inhaled nitric oxide
Definition: This refers to nitric oxide as an inhalant at any time during the patient's admission. Inhaled nitric oxide is tpically used for hypoxic respiratory failure, among other uses.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if inhaled nitric oxide was used any time during this admission.
Metathesaurus: C1135443, Administration of inhaled nitric oxide

Section: ADVANCED CARE INTERVENTIONS: Record all advanced care interventions given from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Tracheostomy inserted
Definition: This refers to the surgical formation of an opening into the trachea through the neck, or the opening so created.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if a tracheostomy was inserted on the patient at any time during admission.

Section: ADVANCED CARE INTERVENTIONS: Record all advanced care interventions given from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Renal replacement therapy (RRT) or dialysis
Definition: This refers to treatments that substitute for the blood-filtering function of the kidneys. It includes dialysis (hemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis), hemofiltration, and hemodiafiltration at any time during the patient's admission.. It may be intermittent or continuous.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient received continuous renal replacement therapy or intermittent haemodialysis at any time during hospitalisation.
Standardized Term Code: 714749008, Continuous renal replacement therapy (procedure) | 895382009, Prolonged intermittent renal replacement therapy (procedure)
Metathesaurus: C3649547, Continuous Renal Replacement Therapy | C5197699, Prolonged Intermittent Renal Replacement Therapy

Section: ADVANCED CARE INTERVENTIONS: Record all advanced care interventions given from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Still ongoing?
Definition: This refers to ongoing renal replacement therapy (RRT) or dialysis
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient is still on renal replacement therapy (RRT) or dialysis

Section: ADVANCED CARE INTERVENTIONS: Record all advanced care interventions given from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Number of calendar days on RRT or dialysis duration during admission
Definition: This refers to the total number of days the patient received RRT or dialysis at any time during this admission.
Completion Guideline: Write the total number of calendar days the patient received RRT or dialysis at any time during this admission. Even if the patient received this more than once in one calendar day (i.e. between 00:00 and 24:00 hours), this counts as one to the total number of days.

Section: ADVANCED CARE INTERVENTIONS: Record all advanced care interventions given from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Inotropes / vasopressors
Definition: This refers to continuous use of a vasopressor or inotrope for at least one hour at any time during the patient's admission.. Agents include norepinephrine, epinephrine, vasopressin, terlipressin and phenylephrine. Commonly used 'positive' inotropes include dobutamine, dopamine, milrinone and adrenaline (epinephrine).
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient received Inotropes / vasopressors for at least one hour at any time during hospitalisation.
Metathesaurus: C5396785, Vasopressor therapy | C5880944, Inotropic therapy

Section: ADVANCED CARE INTERVENTIONS: Record all advanced care interventions given from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Still ongoing?
Definition: This refers to ongoing inotropic/vasoactive therapy.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient is still on inotropic/vasoactive therapy.

Section: ADVANCED CARE INTERVENTIONS: Record all advanced care interventions given from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.
Question: Total inotropes / vasopressor duration during admission (days)
Definition: The refers to the total number of days during this admission that the patient received inotropic/vasoactive therapy.
Completion Guideline: Write the total number of calendar days the patient received inotropic or vasoactive therapy at any time during this admission.

Section: ADVANCED CARE INTERVENTIONS: Record all advanced care interventions given from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome.

Definition: This refers to any other specific critical care therapeutic intervention(s) or procedure(s) not otherwise characterised that you believe may be relevant.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if other critical care intervention(s) or procedure(s) were used at any time during hospitalisation.

Definition: This refers to any other specific critical care therapeutic intervention(s) or procedure(s) not otherwise characterised that you believe may be relevant.

Section: OUTCOME
Question: Was the patient's main diagnosis dengue?
Definition: Referring to this presentation or admission, was this patient's main or primary diagnosis dengue?
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if this patient's main or primary diagnosis dengue at presentation or admission.

Section: OUTCOME
Question: If no: What was the main diagnosis?
Definition: Referring to this presentation or admission, if not dengue, what was the patient's main or primary diagnosis?
Completion Guideline: If not dengue, write the patient's main or primary diagnosis during presentation or admission.

Section: OUTCOME
Question: If yes: What was the final classification of dengue?
Answer Options: 1, Uncomplicated dengue | 2, Dengue with warning signs | 3, Severe dengue
Definition: This refers to the 2009, World Health Organisation dengue classification.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option corresponding to the final classification of dengue (based on the 2009 World Health Organisation dengue classification).
Standardized Term Code: 722862003, Dengue without warning signs (disorder) | 722863008, Dengue with warning signs (disorder) | 20927009, Dengue hemorrhagic fever (disorder)

Section: OUTCOME
Question: Dengue shock syndrome
Definition: Dengue shock syndrome (DSS) refers to severe plasma leakage leading to shock and/or fluid accumulation with respiratory distress.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if the patient experiences this complication of severe dengue which the patient experienced during this admission.

Section: OUTCOME
Question: Severe bleeding
Definition: This refers to severe bleeding as evaluated by clinician.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if the patient experiences this complication of severe dengue which the patient experienced during this admission.

Section: OUTCOME
Question: Severe organ impairment
Definition: This refers to severe organ involvement which can include; Liver involvement is indicated by an AST or ALT greater or equal to 1000 IU/L, nervous system involvement evidenced by impaired consciousness, cardiac involvement (myocarditis), or other organ system involvement.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if the patient experiences this complication of severe dengue which the patient experienced during this admission.

Section: OUTCOME
Question: Was there any secondary diagnosis?
Definition: This refers to a condition(s) that coexists at the time of admission, that develops subsequently, or that affects the treatment received and/or length of stay in addition to the primary or main diagnosis.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if this patient had a secondary diagnosis at presentation or admission.

Section: OUTCOME
Question: Specify secondary diagnosis
Definition: This refers to a condition(s) that coexists at the time of admission, that develops subsequently, or that affects the treatment received and/or length of stay in addition to the primary or main diagnosis.
Completion Guideline: If 'Yes' specify the secondary diagnosis.

Section: OUTCOME
Question: Outcome date
Definition: This refers to the date of the outcome.
Completion Guideline: Write the date of the outcome in the format DD/MM/YYYY.

Section: OUTCOME
Question: Outcome
Answer Options: 1, Discharged alive | 2, Still hospitalised | 3, Transfer to other facility | 4, Death |5, Palliative care | 6, Discharged against medical advice | 7, Alive, not admitted
Definition: This refers to the outcome.

Section: FOLLOW-UP ASSESSMENT
Question: Is the patient's skin damaged following resolution of acute illness
Definition: This refers to the presence of scarring, altered pigmentation, contractures or other deformities secondary to resolved skin lesions.

Section: FOLLOW-UP ASSESSMENT
Question: Select all that apply
Answer Options: 1, Atrophic scars | 2, Hypertrophic scars | 3, Deformities | 4, Hypopigmentation | 5, Hyperpigmentation | 6, Contractures | 88, Other
Definition: This refers to the presence of scarring, altered pigmentation, contractures or other deformities secondary to resolved skin lesions. Atrophic scars refer to scars that form a depression compared to the level of the surrounding skin because of damage to the collagen, fat or other tissues below the skin. Hypertrophic scar refers to a permanent mark on the skin caused by deposits of excessive amounts of collagen during wound healing. It is elevated and does not extend beyond the original boundaries of the wound; the elevation may stabilize or regress spontaneously.  Deformities refer to alterations or deviations from normal shape or size which result in a disfigurement to normal body structures. Hypopigmentation refers to abnormal lightening of skin due to decreased melanin production or deposition. Hyperpigmentation refers to darkening of the skin due to excessive melanin deposition. Contracture refers to a prolonged shortening of the muscle or other soft tissue around a joint, preventing movement of the joint.
Completion Guideline: Select all type(s) of skin damage following resolution of acute illness.

Section: FOLLOW-UP ASSESSMENT
Question: Specify other type of skin damage
Definition: This refers to the presence of any other type(s) of skin damage that you feel is secondary to infection with pathogen of interest, and is pertinent to include here.
Completion Guideline: Write the other type(s) of skin damage following resolution of acute illness.

Section: FOLLOW-UP ASSESSMENT
Question: Does the patient have any sequelae?
Definition: This refers to any other complication(s) or sequalae, not specified above.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if the patient has any other complication(s) or sequalae not specified above.

Section: FOLLOW-UP ASSESSMENT
Question: Select all that apply
Definition: This refers to any other complication(s) or sequalae, not specified above. Decreased vision refers to vision considered to be inferior to normal vision as represented by accepted standards of acuity, field of vision, or motility. Blindness refers to the inability to see or the loss or absence of perception of visual stimuli. Urethral stricture refers to the narrowing of the urethra associated with inflammation or scar tissue. Vaginal stricture refers to narrowing of the vagina owing to scar formation. Rectal stricture refers to narrowing of the rectum secondary to scar formation. Dyspareunia refers to recurrent genital pain occurring during, before, or after sexual intercourse in either the males or the females. Depression refers to an affective disorder manifested by either a dysphoric mood or loss of interest or pleasure in usual activities and the mood disturbance is prominent and relatively persistent.
Completion Guideline: Select all other complication(s) or sequalae, not specified above.

Question: Do you have control over your bowels?
Answer Options: 1, Continent | 2, Occasional incontinence | 3, Frequent incontinence | 4, Incontinent
Definition: This refers to voluntary control of bowel movement. Continent refers to complete voluntary control. Occasional incontinence refers to loss of voluntary control once a week. Frequent incontinence refers to loss of voluntary control more than once a week. Incontinent refers to complete lack of voluntary control, inability to manage alone or requiring use of enemas for bowel movement.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option which most closely corresponds with the patient'scurent level of ability. Record actual, and not potential, functioning.
